title: Disaster Justice in Nepal's Earthquake Recovery
abstract: many policy disaster governance community resilience aim enhancing justice outcome local community level tend focus equal distribution set right good among community however right good defined underlying value structure structure tend mirror interest powerful group community fundamental problem equality right redistribution good remedy disaster injustice taking case study nepal earthquake aim link key work disaster justice theory attempt could help strengthen conceptual foundation policy response disaster recovery nepal case earthquake recovery demonstrate relevance disaster justice lens emphasizes role disaster justice champion critical politics knowledge accountability representation disaster justice conviction demonstrate platform critical knowledge politics important civic science traditional science deliberated interrogated negotiated integrated argue disaster justice champion conviction priority disadvantaged effectively utilizes platform critical knowledge politics possible influence political deliberation decision making potentially enhance disaster justice practice finally theoretical sense argue order enhance disaster justice response need informed understanding justice redistribution well justice recognition
or_abt: Many policies on disaster governance and community resilience aim at enhancing justice outcomes at the local community level. In so doing, they tend to focus on equal distribution of a set of rights and goods among the communities. However, these rights and goods are defined by an underlying value structure, and such structures tend to mirror the interests of the powerful groups in the community. The fundamental problem is that the equality of the rights and redistribution of the goods cannot remedy disaster injustices. Taking a case study from Nepal's earthquake 2015, this paper aims to link key works on disasters with justice theories - an attempt, which could help strengthen the conceptual foundations of policy responses to disaster recovery. We use the Nepal case of earthquake recovery to demonstrate the relevance of disaster justice lens which emphasizes the role of disaster justice champions, critical politics of knowledge, accountability, representation and disaster justice convictions. We demonstrate that the platform of critical knowledge politics is important where civic science and traditional science is deliberated, interrogated, negotiated and integrated. We argue that only when disaster justice champions with convictions of priority to the disadvantaged effectively utilizes the platform of critical knowledge politics, it is possible to influence political deliberations and decision making that can potentially enhance disaster justice in practice. Finally, and in a more theoretical sense, we argue that in order to enhance disaster justice, responses need to be informed by the understanding of ‘justice as redistribution’ as well as ‘justice as recognition’.

title: New Vulnerabilities for Migrants and Refugees in State Responses to the Global Pandemic, COVID-19
abstract: examines global pandemic covid lens response vulnerable migrant asking state response mean future human right value humanitarian intervention response australian state developed case study action policy directed refugee temporary migrant worker covid pandemic theoretical framing draw racial capitalism argue development manifest crisis time covid large part continuity exclusionary politics bordering practice heart neoliberal capitalism proposes rethinking foundational theoretical methodological approach science needed reflect contemporary change justice claim claim increasingly recognize multi specie nature existential threat life
or_abt: This article examines the global pandemic, COVID-19, through the lens of responses to vulnerable migrants, asking what state responses mean for the future of human rights values and for humanitarian interventions. The responses of the Australian state are developed as a case study of actions and policies directed at refugees and temporary migrant workers through the COVID-19 pandemic. The theoretical framing of the article draws on racial capitalism to argue that the developments manifest during the ‘crisis times’ of COVID-19 are in large part a continuity of the exclusionary politics of bordering practices at the heart of neoliberal capitalism. The article proposes that a rethinking of foundational theoretical and methodological approaches in the social sciences are needed to reflect contemporary changes in justice claims, claims that increasingly recognize the multi-species nature of existential threats to all life.

title: Digital mapping as feminist method: critical reflections
abstract: digital map taken productive tool activism academic however le consideration method qualitative science aim contribute towards scholarship qualitative providing critical reflection digital mapping method feminist project street based harassment australia drawing practice reflexivity well comment made participant across qualitative interview consider digital mapping facilitate feminist arguing represents generative instrument lends development depth insight participant yet mapping delimits epistemological possibility qualitative consider method simultaneously constrains known street harassment
or_abt: Digital maps have been taken up as a productive tool in both activism and academic research. However, there has been less consideration of their use as a research method in qualitative social sciences research. This paper aims to contribute towards scholarship on qualitative research by providing a critical reflection on the use of digital mapping as a research method in a feminist research project on street-based harassment in Australia. Drawing on practices of reflexivity, as well as comments made by participants across 46 qualitative interviews, I consider how digital mapping can be used to facilitate feminist research, arguing that it represents a generative instrument which lends itself to the development of in-depth insights from participants. Yet, mapping also delimits the epistemological possibilities of qualitative research, and I consider how this method simultaneously constrains what can be known about street harassment.

title: The Qualitative Report Digital Storytelling in Research: A Systematic Review
authers: ['Adele de Jager', 'Andrea S Fogarty', 'Anna Tewson[...]', 'Katherine Boydell']
abstract: digital storytelling refers minute audio visual clip combining photograph voice narration audio lambert originally applied community development artistic therapeutic purpose recently adapted art based method date systematic digital storytelling capacity generate information phenomenon conducted accordingly aim provide systematic digital storytelling identified article representing discrete study met inclusion criterion thematic result indicated digital storytelling especially appropriate marginalised group commonly context variation extent digital storytelling adhered principle originally developed surprisingly although digital storytelling provides ready made knowledge translation product project employed digital story generated end across project participant reported several benefit digital storytelling disadvantage noted overall outweighed benefit using respectful participatory practice adële de jager andrea fogarty anna tewson caroline lenette katherine boydell nova southeastern university
or_abt: Digital storytelling refers to a 2 to 5 minute audio-visual clip combining photographs, voice-over narration, and other audio (Lambert, 2009) originally applied for community development, artistic and therapeutic purposes, and more recently adapted as an arts-based research method. To date, no systematic review of the use of digital storytelling in a research capacity, to generate information about a phenomenon has been conducted. Accordingly, our aim was to provide a systematic review of digital storytelling in research. The review identified 25 articles representing 23 discrete studies that met inclusion criteria. A thematic analysis of results indicated that digital storytelling in research was especially appropriate for use with marginalised groups, and was most commonly used in this context. There was some variation in the extent to which digital storytelling in research adhered to the principles with which it was originally developed. Surprisingly, although digital storytelling provides a ready-made knowledge translation product, few research projects employed the digital stories generated to this end. Across research projects, participants reported several benefits of digital storytelling. While some disadvantages were noted, overall, these were outweighed by the benefits of using a respectful, participatory research practice. © 2017: Adële de Jager, Andrea Fogarty, Anna Tewson, Caroline Lenette, Katherine M. Boydell, and Nova Southeastern University.

title: Child sexual abuse material on the darknet: A script analysis of how offenders operate
abstract: development online technology recent decade facilitated distribution consumption child sexual abuse material csam internet led emergence csam darknet segment internet hidden general public using obtained interview online investigator study us crime script reconstruct step step offender operate darknet finding highlight three phase script crime setup phase crime completion phase crime continuation phase scripting practical method developing concrete way address problem implication using crime script fight csam discussed
or_abt: The development of online technologies in recent decades has facilitated the distribution and consumption of child sexual abuse material (CSAM) over the internet, which also led to the emergence of CSAM on the darknet-the segment of the internet hidden from the general public. Using data obtained from interviews with online investigators, this study uses crime script analysis to reconstruct step-by-step how offenders operate on the darknet. The findings highlight the three phases of the script: (1) the crime setup phase, (2) the crime completion phase, and (3) the crime continuation phase. Scripting is a practical method of developing concrete ways to address this problem. The implications of using crime scripts to fight CSAM are discussed.

title: The Danish Cartoons, Charlie Hebdo and the culture wars: satiric limits in comparative national and transnational perspectives
abstract: considerable body academic lauded political satirist rebellious defender democracy free speech establishment although satire always rebellious reputation satirist satire may object partisan capture object capture right wing populist respect satire meta discourse satire like political rhetoric gathering like minded ally claiming standard fighting opponent danish cartoon crisis charlie hebdo massacre proponent culture war rhetoric added satire list western cultural legacy needed defence islamic terrorism well left authoritarian elite suppressed free speech political correctness constructed simplistic global political dichotomy satire free speech civilisation lifted event local context process global framing culture war rhetoric absolutist support free speech satire international level national level reveals hortatory partisan side rhetoric complexity belie absolutist stand nation arena struggle free speech political humour played
or_abt: A considerable body of academic literature has lauded political satirists as rebellious defenders of democracy and free speech against an establishment. Although satire is not always rebellious, this reputation of satirists and of satire may itself be the object of partisan capture. In this article, it is the object of capture by right-wing populists. In that respect, satire and the meta-discourse about satire can be used like any political rhetoric in gathering like-minded allies, claiming standards, and fighting opponents. With the Danish cartoons crisis of 2005-2006 and the Charlie Hebdo massacre of 2015, proponents of culture wars rhetoric added satire to their list of Western cultural legacies that needed defence against Islamic terrorism as well as left authoritarian elites who suppressed free speech through political correctness. They constructed simplistic global political dichotomies about satire, free speech, and civilisation and lifted events out of local contexts in a process of global framing. The culture war rhetoric was absolutist in support of free speech and satire on the international level. But the national level reveals the hortatory and partisan side to this rhetoric and the complexities that belie the absolutist stand. Nations are the arenas where struggles over free speech and political humour are played out.

title: Importance of sex education for a successful transition to life after school: Experiences of high school girls with intellectual disability
abstract: accessible summary quality sex education important student help successful transition life school talked australian high school girl intellectual disability wanted know think sex education school girl told u often included individual learning plan meeting consulted would like learn sex education sex education class largely inaccessible accessible sex education class important prepare student life school abstract background student intellectual disability often receive holistic sex education critical successful transition post school life including ability make healthy choice sexuality relationship aim inclusive study explore perception experience sex education australian high school girl intellectual disability prepare transition post school life method high school girl aged year participated study interview conducted analysed using inductive content finding finding indicate critical topic gender sexual identity masturbation sufficiently covered sex education new south wale australia participating girl highlighted way teacher could make sex education lesson accessible individual learning plan meeting important platform transition planning attended le third girl study conclusion comprehensive accessible programme sex educati read
or_abt:
Accessible summary • Quality sex education is important for all students. It also helps with a successful transition to life after school. • We talked to 11 Australian high school girls with intellectual disability. We wanted to know what they think about their sex education at school. • The girls told us that they were often not included in Individual Learning Plan meetings. They were also not consulted about what they would like to learn in sex education. • Sex education classes were largely inaccessible for them. • Accessible sex education classes are important to prepare students for life after school. Abstract 1.1 Background Students with intellectual disability often do not receive holistic sex education, which is critical for their successful transition to post-school life, including having an ability to make healthy choices about their sexuality and relationships. The aim of this inclusive research study was to explore the perceptions and experiences of sex education with Australian high school girls with intellectual disability, as they prepare for a transition to post-school life. 1.2 Method There were 11 high school girls aged 13–20 years who participated in this study. Interviews were conducted and analysed using inductive content analysis. 1.3 Findings The findings indicate that critical topics such as gender and sexual identity, and masturbation are not sufficiently covered in sex education in New South Wales, Australia. The participating girls also highlighted ways in which teachers could make sex education lessons more accessible. Individual Learning Plan meetings, an important platform for transition planning, were attended by less than a third of the girls in this study. 1.4 Conclusions Comprehensive and accessible programmes on sex educati

title: Impact of national guidelines on use of BRCA1/2 germline testing, risk management advice given to women with pathogenic BRCA1/2 variants and uptake of advice
abstract: background nationwide study assessed impact nationally agreed cancer genetics guideline brca germline testing risk management advice given health professional woman pathogenic brca variant uptake advice patient method clinic file woman initial proband screen brca pathogenic variant familial cancer clinic july july e guideline release july july july july guideline release audited determine reason given genetic testing separately clinic file female carrier without personal history breast ovarian cancer underwent brca predictive genetic testing received result pre post guideline audited ascertain risk management advice given health professional carrier included audit invited participate telephone interview ass uptake advice agreed participate result significant change percentage tested patient meeting least published indication genetic testing file met criterion guideline four year post guideline respectively χ p rate documentation post test risk management advice per guideline increased significantly pre post guideline risk management strategy strategy highest compliance amongst carrier awareness post release guideline annual magnetic resonance imaging plus mammography woman year annual mammography woman year woman aged year risk reducing bi read
or_abt:
Background This nationwide study assessed the impact of nationally agreed cancer genetics guidelines on use of BRCA1/2 germline testing, risk management advice given by health professionals to women with pathogenic BRCA1/2 variants and uptake of such advice by patients. Methods Clinic files of 883 women who had initial proband screens for BRCA1/2 pathogenic variants at 12 familial cancer clinics between July 2008–July 2009 (i.e. before guideline release), July 2010–July 2011 and July 2012–July 2013 (both after guideline release) were audited to determine reason given for genetic testing. Separately, the clinic files of 599 female carriers without a personal history of breast/ovarian cancer who underwent BRCA1/2 predictive genetic testing and received their results pre- and post-guideline were audited to ascertain the risk management advice given by health professionals. Carriers included in this audit were invited to participate in a telephone interview to assess uptake of advice, and 329 agreed to participate. Results There were no significant changes in the percentages of tested patients meeting at least one published indication for genetic testing - 79, 77 and 78% of files met criteria before guideline, and two-, and four-years post-guideline, respectively (χ = 0.25, p = 0.88). Rates of documentation of post-test risk management advice as per guidelines increased significantly from pre- to post-guideline for 6/9 risk management strategies. The strategies with the highest compliance amongst carriers or awareness post-release of guidelines were annual magnetic resonance imaging plus mammography in women 30–50 years (97%) and annual mammography in women > 50 years (92%). Of women aged over 40 years, 41% had a risk-reducing bi

title: Perspectives of professionals on the safety and accessibility of aged care for Care Leavers and Forgotten Australians
abstract: objective little known prepared aged care system meet specific need care leaver forgotten australian explored service provider advocate perspective barrier facilitator appropriate safe care group method three focus group sixteen professional stakeholder examined way aged care support accessible inaccessible forgotten australian result participant noted structural organisational feature act barrier best practice aged care perceived funding model process provide insufficient opportunity develop trust professional access tailored care engaged aged care service sector lack psychological literacy required tailor care manage complex need preference forgotten australian conclusion systemic organisational change promotes increased flexibility trauma informed care non residential housing option improve safety accessibility aged care forgotten australian
or_abt: Objectives: Little is known about how prepared the aged care system is to meet the specific needs of Care Leavers and Forgotten Australians. We explored service provider and advocate perspectives about the barriers and facilitators for appropriate and safe care for this group. Methods: Three focus groups with sixteen professional stakeholders examined the ways aged care support is accessible and inaccessible for Forgotten Australians. Results: Participants noted structural and organisational features that act as barriers to best practice aged care. It was perceived that funding models and processes provide insufficient opportunity to develop trust with professionals and access tailored care. Once engaged with aged care services, the sector lacks the psychological literacy required to tailor care to manage the complex needs and preferences of Forgotten Australians. Conclusion: Systemic and organisational change that promotes increased flexibility, trauma-informed care and non-residential housing options will improve the safety and accessibility of aged care for Forgotten Australians.

title: Benefit of China’s Social Health Insurance Schemes: Trend Analysis and Associated Factors Since Health Reform
abstract: deepening health insurance reform china integration health insurance scheme put agenda aim illustrate achievement gap integration demonstrating trend benefit available three health insurance scheme well influencing factor drawn three wave china health nutrition undertaken since health reform commenced χ kruskalwallis test part model employed overall reimbursement rate urban employee basic medical insurance uebmi higher urban resident basic medical insurance urbmi new rural cooperative medical scheme nrcms p gap narrowed since health reform began outpatient inpatient reimbursement amount increased urbmi nrcms illness severity higher institutional level inpatient service associated significant increase amount reimbursement received across three wave health reform improved benefit covered urbmi nrcms gap uebmi still exist government consider release health benefit lead toward healthcare equity
or_abt: With the deepening of health insurance reform in China, the integration of social health insurance schemes was put on the agenda. This paper aims to illustrate the achievements and the gaps in integration by demonstrating the trends in benefits available from the three social health insurance schemes, as well as the influencing factors. Data were drawn from the three waves of the China Health and Nutrition Survey (2009, 2011, 2015) undertaken since health reforms commenced. χ2, Kruskal–Wallis test, and the Two-Part model were employed in the analysis. The overall reimbursement rate of the Urban Employee Basic Medical Insurance (UEBMI) is higher than that of Urban Resident Basic Medical Insurance (URBMI) or the New Rural Cooperative Medical Scheme (NRCMS) (p < 0.001), but the gap has narrowed since health reform began in 2009. Both the outpatient and inpatient reimbursement amounts have increased through the URBMI and NRCMS. Illness severity, higher institutional level, and inpatient service were associated with significant increases in the amount of reimbursement received across the three survey waves. The health reform improved benefits covered by the URBMI and NRCMS, but gaps with the UEBMI still exist. The government should consider more the release of health benefits and how to lead toward healthcare equity.

title: Embracing the future: an evaluation of sexuality workshops for parents and carers of children and young people with intellectual disability and autism spectrum disorders
abstract: background evidence show parent carers often resourced lacking confidence awareness supporting child young person intellectual disability id autism spectrum disorder asd puberty sexuality relationship method family planning nsw funded nib foundation delivered six workshop parent carers across nsw focussing puberty sexuality relationship education child young people id asd pre post workshop survey completed participant n three month follow via online telephone interview evaluate effectiveness workshop quantitative analysed using stata qualitative summarised theme analysed nvivo using thematic analysis result significant improvement participant knowledge confidence level providing sexuality support child young person pre post workshop found across respondent gain retained three month follow respondent identified barrier supporting child young person including lack understanding adapt information effectively child need lack time scarcity workshop resource regional area implication provision sexuality workshop build knowledge confidence parent carers highly valuable however improving sexuality support provided child young people focus identifying minimising barrier providing support
or_abt: Background: Evidence shows that parents and carers are often under resourced and lacking confidence and awareness in supporting their child or young person with intellectual disability (ID) and autism spectrum disorders (ASD) with puberty, sexuality and relationships. Method: In 2018, Family Planning NSW (funded by nib Foundation) delivered six workshops to parents and carers across NSW focussing on puberty, sexuality and relationships education for children and young people with ID and ASD. Pre and post workshop surveys were completed by participants (n = 116) with a three month follow-up via online survey or telephone interview to evaluate the effectiveness of the workshop. Quantitative data was analysed using STATA 14.0. Qualitative data was summarised by theme or analysed in Nvivo using thematic analyses. Results: A significant improvement in participants’ knowledge and confidence level in providing sexuality support to their child/young person between the pre- and post-workshop survey was found across survey respondents, with those gains retained at the three month follow up. Respondents also identified barriers in supporting their child or young person, including lack of understanding about how to adapt information effectively to their child’s needs, lack of time, and a scarcity of workshops and resources in regional areas. Implications: The provision of sexuality workshops to build the knowledge and confidence of parents and carers is highly valuable. However, improving the sexuality support provided to children and young people should also focus on identifying and minimising barriers to providing that support.

title: A Comparative Content Analysis of Pre-Internet and Contemporary Child Sexual Abuse Material
abstract: child sexual abuse material recognised major problem however prior internet disclosure victimisation abuse material subject sceptical scholarly commentary veracity sceptical position subject limited empirical scrutiny aim study analyse content sample image pre internet abuse material pre internet sample analysed according characteristic victim perpetrator severity setting abuse compared pre existing dataset contemporary abuse image finding study underscore severity pre internet abuse material comparison pre internet contemporary sample found average age girl abused abuse material decreased severity material increased study highlight significant abuse experienced abuse material victim prior internet suggests popularisation internet linked trend towards serious offending child abuse material consistent role home major site abuse material production pose significant challenge prevention early intervention prosecution
or_abt: Child sexual abuse material is now recognised as a major social problem however, prior to the internet, disclosures of victimisation in abuse material were the subject of sceptical scholarly commentary. The veracity of the sceptical position has been subject to limited empirical scrutiny. The aim of this study is to analyse the content of a sample of 1004 images of pre-internet abuse material. The pre-internet sample was analysed according to the characteristics of victim/s, perpetrator/s and severity and setting of abuse, which were then compared to a pre-existing dataset of 34,561 contemporary abuse images. The findings of the study underscore the severity of pre-internet abuse material. The comparison between the pre-internet and contemporary sample found that the average age of girls abused in abuse material has decreased, and the severity of the material has increased. The study highlights the significant abuse experienced by abuse material victims prior to the internet, and suggests the popularisation of the internet is linked to a trend towards more serious offending against children in abuse material. The consistent role of the home as the major site of abuse material production poses significant challenges to prevention, early intervention and prosecution.

title: Land rights in peacebuilding discourse: domination and resistance in Timor-Leste’s Ita Nia Rai program
abstract: development land right program deeply rooted power relation using discourse unpacks western logic assumption convention regarding best practice property right institution tenure security impact design peacebuilding program government timor leste passed controversial land law package law initially developed usaid land reform program local dynamic action interest ignored examining civil society exclusion decision making infers reluctance acknowledge local voice practice threaten liberal peacebuilding interest organised part first argue peacebuilding best practice reflect dominant western discourse create conceptual boundary violent hierarchy restrict recognition indigenous idea legitimate second examine timorese civil society effort improve land reform program act resistance body authority overall illuminate timor leste western assumption convention contributed boundary local participation contradicts liberal narrative empowerment capacity building
or_abt: The development of land rights programs is deeply rooted in power relations. Using discourse analysis, this paper unpacks how Western logics (assumptions and conventions) regarding ‘best practices’ for property rights institutions and tenure security impact the design of peacebuilding programs. In 2017, the Government of Timor-Leste passed a controversial Land Law Package. These laws were initially developed for a USAID land reform program. But local dynamics, actions, and interests were ignored. Examining civil society exclusion from decision-making infers a reluctance to acknowledge local voices and practices that threaten liberal peacebuilding interests. This paper is organised into two parts. In the first, we argue that peacebuilding ‘best practices’ reflect how dominant Western discourses create conceptual boundaries (‘violent hierarchies’) to restrict the recognition of indigenous ideas as legitimate. In the second, we examine Timorese civil society efforts to improve the land reform program through acts of resistance to bodies of authority. Overall, we illuminate how in Timor-Leste Western assumptions and conventions contributed to boundaries to local participation, which contradicts liberal narratives of empowerment and capacity-building.

title: Social and emotional wellbeing of indigenous gender and sexuality diverse youth: mapping the evidence
abstract: little exploration emotional wellbeing young indigenous population identify gender sexuality diverse given vulnerability cohort settler colonial society australia canada usa wider investigation called order respond need aspiration using scoping map existing intersection youth gender sexuality diversity indigeneity wellbeing evidence point importance historical contemporary experience tied colonisation intergenerational trauma young indigenous gender sexuality diverse people heteronormative colonial value system converge produce environment characterised racism phobia marginalisation evidence base includes deficit model based trauma negative outcome however emerging body highlighting resistance resilience indigenous gender sexuality diverse youth
or_abt: There has been little exploration of the social and emotional wellbeing of young Indigenous populations who identify as gender and sexuality diverse. Given the vulnerability of this cohort in settler colonial societies such as Australia, Canada and the USA, wider investigation is called for in order to respond to their needs and aspirations. Using a scoping review, this paper maps existing research on the intersections of youth, gender and sexuality diversity, Indigeneity and wellbeing. The evidence points to the importance of historical and contemporary experiences tied to colonisation and intergenerational trauma. For young Indigenous gender and sexuality diverse peoples, heteronormative colonial value systems converge to produce environments characterised by racism, phobia and marginalisation. The evidence base includes deficit models based on trauma and negative outcomes. However, there is also an emerging body of research highlighting the resistance and resilience of Indigenous gender and sexuality diverse youth.

title: Exiting prison with complex support needs: the role of housing assistance
abstract: examined policy program relevant housing pathway ex prisoner complex support need nsw victoria tasmania including criminal justice cost benefit result current housing assistance setting
or_abt: This research examined policies and programs relevant to the housing pathways of ex-prisoners with complex support needs in NSW, Victoria and Tasmania, including what criminal justice costs and benefits result from current housing assistance settings.

title: Elder Mediation Services Among Diverse Older Adult Communities in Australia: Practitioner Perspectives on Accessibility
abstract: background objective elder abuse complex problem barrier reporting help seeking include shame fear loss relationship key family member elder mediation identified promising method alternative dispute resolution study aimed investigate accessibility elder mediation service among diverse group older adult perspective practitioner large australian jurisdiction design method study employed sequential mixed method approach comprising thematic semi structured interview n online practitioner n involved referral provision elder mediation service accessibility conceptualized using existing theoretical framework spanning practical logistics related normative justice culture related dimension result factor limiting accessibility elder mediation service included lack community practitioner awareness elder abuse elder mediation discomfort mediation process financial cost lack service regional remote area complex service system older people within mediation process difficulty assessing accommodating cognitive impairment managing power imbalance determining appropriateness dispute mediation influential discussion implication study showed mediation promising effective approach resolving dispute involving older people emergent perceptive dimension community practitioner awareness emphasizes importance awareness raising effort surrounding elder abus read
or_abt:
Background and objectives: Elder abuse is a complex problem, and barriers to reporting and help-seeking include shame and fear of loss of relationships with key family members. Elder-mediation has been identified as one promising method of alternative dispute resolution. This study aimed to investigate the accessibility of elder-mediation services among diverse groups of older adults, from the perspective of practitioners in a large Australian jurisdiction. Research design and methods: The study employed a sequential mixed-methods approach, comprising a thematic analysis of semi-structured interviews (N=17) and an online survey of practitioners (N=49) involved in referral to, or provision of, elder-mediation services. Accessibility was conceptualized using existing theoretical frameworks, spanning practical (logistics-related) and normative (justice and culture-related) dimensions. Results: Factors limiting accessibility of elder-mediation services included lack of community and practitioner awareness of elder abuse and elder-mediation, discomfort with the mediation process, financial costs, lack of services in regional and remote areas and complex service systems for older people. Within the mediation process, difficulties in assessing and accommodating cognitive and other impairments, managing power imbalances and determining the appropriateness of the dispute for mediation were influential. Discussion and implications: This study showed that mediation can be a promising and effective approach to resolving disputes involving older people. The emergent perceptive dimension (community and practitioner awareness) emphasizes the importance of awareness raising efforts surrounding both elder abus

title: Outcomes of routine screening for reproductive coercion in a family planning service
abstract: background reproductive coercion rc occurs person autonomous decision making regarding reproductive health compromised another rc screening routine non invasive screening question asked service user client strategy ass rc routine screening rc implemented within family planning nsw clinical consultation december cross sectional study undertaken outcome screening better understand situation rc among woman accessing family planning service method retrospective clinical consultation eligible woman attending family planning nsw clinic undertaken descriptive conducted modified poisson regression estimate prevalence ratio ass association binary outcome client characteristic result woman eligible rc screening screened woman disclosed rc rc likely disclosed among client unemployed disability visit within year conclusion sexual reproductive health clinician particular well placed conduct rc screening however must adequate training access resource implement screening respond woman disclose rc
or_abt: Background: Reproductive coercion (RC) occurs when a person's autonomous decision-making regarding reproductive health is compromised by another. RC screening, that is, the use of routine, non-invasive screening questions asked of service users/clients, is one strategy that can be used to assess for RC. Routine screening for RC was implemented within Family Planning NSW clinical consultations in December 2018. A cross-sectional study was undertaken to review the outcomes of screening to better understand the situation of RC among women accessing family planning services. Methods: A retrospective review of clinical consultation data of eligible women attending Family Planning NSW clinics in 2019 was undertaken. Descriptive analysis was conducted and modified Poisson regression was used to estimate prevalence ratios and assess associations between binary outcomes and client characteristics. Results: Of 7943 women eligible for RC screening, 5497 were screened (69%) and 127 women (2.3%) disclosed RC. RC was more likely to be disclosed among clients who were unemployed, had a disability or had more than one visit within 1 year. Conclusions: Sexual and reproductive health clinicians, in particular, are well placed to conduct RC screening. However, they must have adequate training and access to resources to implement screening and respond to women who disclose RC.

title: Characteristics and Impacts of Sexual Violence Against Men and Boys in Conflict and Displacement: A Multicountry Exploratory Study
abstract: evidence sexual violence men boy many conflict affected setting increasingly recognized yet relatively little currently known varied form site impact violence scant sexual violence men boy displacement context undertaken date begin address knowledge gap undertook multicountry qualitative exploratory study gain insight issue study setting population rohingya refugee bangladesh refugee migrant traveled libya residing italy refugee eastern democratic republic congo drc somalia south sudan residing nairobi mombasa kenya method included semi structured focus group discussion refugee semi structured key informant interview aid worker woman refugee commission journal interpersonal violence human right expert thematically analyzed using nvivo finding suggest sexual violence men boy may rare myanmar northern rakhine state libya eastern drc south sudan frequently reported form violence setting genital violence forced witnessing sexual violence rape site violence often reported included border crossing along roadside imprisonment host country form sexual violence included sexual abuse boy sexual exploitation particularly adolescent person diverse sexual orientation gender identity rape impact survivor involved short long term physical mental economic familial dimension finding aim read
or_abt:
Evidence of sexual violence against men and boys in many conflict-affected settings is increasingly recognized. Yet relatively little is currently known about the varied forms, sites, and impacts of this violence. Further, scant research on sexual violence against men and boys in displacement contexts has been undertaken to date. To begin to address these knowledge gaps, we undertook a multicountry, qualitative, exploratory study to gain insights into these issues. Study settings and populations were Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh; refugees and migrants who had traveled through Libya residing in Italy; and refugees from eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), Somalia, and South Sudan residing in Nairobi and Mombasa, Kenya. Methods included 55 semi-structured focus group discussions with 310 refugees and semi-structured key informant interviews with 148 aid workers 1 Women's Refugee Commission, 2 Journal of Interpersonal Violence and human rights experts. Data were thematically analyzed using NVivo 12. Findings suggest that sexual violence against men and boys may not be rare in Myanmar (northern Rakhine state), Libya, eastern DRC, and South Sudan. Frequently reported forms of violence in these settings were genital violence, forced witnessing of sexual violence, and rape. Sites where violence was often reported included border crossings, along the roadside, and during imprisonment. In host countries, forms of sexual violence included sexual abuse of boys, sexual exploitation particularly of adolescents and persons with diverse sexual orientation and gender identity, and rape. Impacts on survivors involved short-and long-term physical, mental, economic, and familial dimensions. These findings aim

title: Mothers & Daughters : Redefining Cultural Continuity Through South Sudanese Women’s Artistic Practices
abstract: group south sudanese woman came together share artistic cultural practice another series creative workshop community art gallery sydney australia collaborated woman organise workshop activity community event showcase cultural artefact item created workshop art partnership documented woman conversation artistic cultural tradition practice weekly gathering pre post workshop discussion suggests woman involved participant designed driven workshop redefining culture cultural practice different place shaped new notion cultural continuity defined process maintaining passing traditional knowledge conceptualised cultural tradition everyday practice lived reality point connection past creation woman space artistic practice resettlement context provided regular opportunity woman different age discus culturally prescribed gender norm tradition candidly participant led art collaboration represent flexible approach exploring woman notion art culture gender based experience understand navigate everyday reality
or_abt: A group of South Sudanese women came together in 2018 to share artistic and cultural practices with one another during a series of creative workshops at a community art gallery in Sydney, Australia. We collaborated with the women to organise workshop activities and a community event to showcase their cultural artefacts and items created during the workshops. Through a research-arts partnership, we documented women’s conversations about their artistic and cultural traditions and practices during weekly gatherings and pre and post-workshop discussions. This paper suggests that the women involved in these participant-designed and driven workshops were redefining their culture and cultural practices in a different place, and shaped new notions of cultural continuity, defined as the process of maintaining and passing on traditional knowledge. They conceptualised cultural traditions as everyday practices in their lived realities, and as points of connections with the past. The creation of a women-only space for artistic practices in a resettlement context provided regular opportunities for women of different ages to discuss culturally-prescribed gender norms and traditions candidly. Participant-led research-arts collaborations represent a flexible approach to exploring women’s notions of art and culture and gender-based experiences to understand how they navigate everyday social realities.

title: Adapting Service Delivery during COVID-19: Experiences of Domestic Violence Practitioners
abstract: covid rapidly altered pattern domestic family violence increasing complexity woman need presenting new barrier service examines service response australia exploring practitioner account adapting service delivery model early month pandemic qualitatively enriched online practitioner n show way service rapidly shifted engage client via remote technology mediated mode physical distancing requirement triggered rapid expansion phone email video call messaging many face face intervention temporarily ceased many practitioner service manager found remote service delivery improved accessibility efficiency others expressed concern capacity ass risk without face face contact unsure whether new service modality would meet need client group reflect best practice finding attest practitioner mixed experience period rapid service innovation change underline importance monitoring emerging approach establish service adaptation effective different group people determine good practice combining remote face face service option longer term
or_abt: COVID-19 rapidly altered patterns of domestic and family violence, increasing the complexity of women’s needs, and presenting new barriers to service use. This article examines service responses in Australia, exploring practitioners' accounts of adapting service delivery models in the early months of the pandemic. Data from a qualitatively enriched online survey of practitioners (n = 100) show the ways services rapidly shifted to engage with clients via remote, technology-mediated modes, as physical distancing requirements triggered rapid expansion in the use of phone, email, video calls and messaging, and many face-to-face interventions temporarily ceased. Many practitioners and service managers found that remote service delivery improved accessibility and efficiency. Others expressed concerns about their capacity to assess risk without face-to-face contact, and were unsure whether new service modalities would meet the needs of all client groups and reflect best practice. Findings attest to practitioners' mixed experiences during this period of rapid service innovation and change, and underline the importance of monitoring emerging approaches to establish which service adaptations are effective for different groups of people, and to determine good practice for combining remote and face-to-face service options in the longer term.

title: Social Exclusion/Inclusion and Australian First Nations LGBTIQ+ Young People’s Wellbeing
abstract: little known cultural emotional wellbeing scewb aboriginal torres strait islander lgbtiq young people australia exists disaggregate young people experience adult aboriginal torres strait islander lgbtiq peer form basis first conducted australia topic us information depth interview inform concept inclusion exclusion population group interview demonstrate different way inclusion exclusion practice pattern process within first nation community non indigenous lgbtiq community impact scewb young people demonstrates importance acceptance support family particular centrality mother young people feeling accepted safe able successfully overcome challenge scewb non indigenous urban lgbtiq community time seen second family young people however structural racism within community seen problem young people inclusion contributes significant new evidence impact inclusion exclusion scewb australian first nation lgbtiq youth
or_abt: There is little known about the social, cultural and emotional wellbeing (SCEWB) of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander LGBTIQ+ young people in Australia. What research exists does not disaggregate young people’s experiences from those of their adult Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander LGBTIQ+ peers. The research that forms the basis for this article is one of the first conducted in Australia on this topic. The article uses information from in-depth interviews to inform concepts of social inclusion and exclusion for this population group. The interviews demonstrate the different ways in which social inclusion/exclusion practices, patterns and process within First Nations communities and non-Indigenous LGBTIQ+ communities impact on the SCEWB of these young people. The research demonstrates the importance of acceptance and support from families in particular the centrality of mothers to young people feeling accepted, safe and able to successfully overcome challenges to SCEWB. Non-Indigenous urban LGBTIQ+ communities are at times seen as a “second family” for young people, however, structural racism within these communities is also seen as a problem for young people’s inclusion. This article contributes significant new evidence on the impact of inclusion/exclusion on the SCEWB of Australian First Nations LGBTIQ+ youth.

title: Young Carers in Australia: Understanding Experiences of Caring and Support-Seeking Behaviour
authers: ['Isaac Yeboah Addo', 'Sienna Aguilar', 'Sarah Judd-Lam[...]', 'Abner Weng Cheong Poon']
abstract: although young carers experience several challenge associated role little known current effect challenge education work life support seeking behaviour researched based finding interview focus group discussion qualitative study present insight effect providing informal care life young carers support seeking behaviour participant reported several physical mental effect caring either positive negative implication life whereas providing care influenced early maturity self efficacy formation stronger bond care recipient limited participant ability find work focus education socialise peer utilisation formal community based professional support service low among participant stigma associated label carer lack youth friendly service setting lack self identification carer status lack cultural age specific support service different stage caring constrained support service among participant contrast positive attitude service provider encouraged support service finding highlight urgent need professional support young carers implication failure provide sufficient professional support young carers aggravate negative consequence associated caring role worker professional strengthen collaboration educator work supervisor support agency address challenge providing care young age given caring role read
or_abt:
Although young carers experience several challenges associated with their roles, little is known about the current effects of those challenges on their education, work, and social life. Their support-seeking behaviour is also under-researched. Based on findings from 25 interviews and a focus group discussion, this qualitative study presents insights into the effects of providing informal care on the lives of young carers and their support-seeking behaviour. Participants reported several physical, mental, and social effects of caring that have either positive or negative implications for their lives. Whereas providing care influenced early maturity, self-efficacy, and formation of stronger bonds with care recipients, it also limited participants’ ability to find work, focus on their education, and socialise with peers. Utilisation of formal community-based and professional support services was low among the participants. Stigma associated with the label “carer”; lack of youth-friendly service settings; lack of self-identification of carer status; and a lack of cultural, age, and specific support services for different stages of caring constrained the use of support services among participants. In contrast, positive attitudes of service providers encouraged the use of support services. These findings highlight an urgent need for more professional support for young carers. • IMPLICATIONS • Failure to provide sufficient professional support to young carers can aggravate the negative consequences associated with their caring roles. • Social workers and other professionals can strengthen their collaboration with educators, work supervisors, and other support agencies to address the challenges of providing care at a young age. • Given that caring roles

title: Sintering expansion behavior and expansion mechanism of Cu-Ni-Al powder alloy
abstract: cu ni al alloy prepared compression molding cu ni al powder sintering behavior expansion mechanism cu ni al system powder alloy investigated result show considerable expansion occurs sintered c accompanied decrease density increase porosity measurement including differential thermal edax metallographic observation conducted proved compact perform larger faster expansion appearance al rich melt form reaction al cu ni c al rich melt penetrates grain boundary cu particle leaf pore prior al particle site large solubility al cu ni al rich melt finally absorbed solid result unbalanced diffusion component leading net mass flow solid liquid interface brings solid particle grain growth increase volume specimen whole
or_abt: Cu-10Ni-1.25Al alloy was prepared by compression molding with Cu, Ni and Al powder. The sintering behavior and expansion mechanism of Cu-Ni-Al system powder alloy were investigated. The results show that considerable expansion occurs after being sintered at 600-800°C, accompanied by the decrease of density and increase of porosity. The measurements including differential thermal analysis, EDAX analysis and metallographic observation were conducted, and it is proved that the compacts perform the larger and faster expansion after the appearance of Al-rich melt which forms by the reaction of Al with Cu and Ni at 600°C. Al-rich melt penetrates into the grain boundaries of Cu particles and leaves pores at the prior Al particle sites. Because of a large solubility of Al in the Cu and Ni, Al-rich melt is finally absorbed into the solid as a result of unbalanced diffusion between components, leading to the net mass flow between the solid/liquid interfaces, which brings about the solid particle grain growth and the increase in the volume of the specimen as a whole.

title: When Following the Rules Is Bad for Wellbeing: The Effects of Gendered Rules in the Australian Construction Industry
abstract: construction industry known highly masculinised work practice detrimental employee wellbeing drawing feminist institutional theory rapid ethnographic approach construction multinationals australia examine relationship gendered nature construction workplace wellbeing professional woman men employed industry finding reveal adhering gendered rule construction industry negatively associated wellbeing usually endured silence identify way gendered rule different effect wellbeing men woman conclude construction industry characterised set greedy gendered institution inextricably linked workplace wellbeing men woman rule must broken improve worker wellbeing
or_abt: The construction industry is known to be highly masculinised and to have work practices detrimental to employees’ wellbeing. Drawing on feminist institutional theory and a rapid ethnographic approach in two construction multinationals in Australia, we examine the relationship between the gendered nature of construction and workplace wellbeing for professional women and men employed in the industry. The findings reveal that adhering to the gendered ‘rules in use’ in the construction industry is negatively associated with wellbeing and is usually endured in silence. We also identify the ways in which the gendered rules have different effects on the wellbeing of men and women. We conclude that the construction industry is characterised by a set of ‘greedy’ gendered institutions that are inextricably linked to workplace wellbeing for both men and women and that these rules must be broken to improve worker wellbeing.

title: Greening Sydney: attitudes, barriers and opportunities for tree planting
abstract: understanding people attitude towards urban forest crucial advance sustainability goal proposing policy change local government global city sydney becoming highly multi cultural vital local government city responsive diverse voice interest resident investigates attitude people different socio economic background thereby identifies barrier opportunity tree planting analysing socio economically diverse local government area lgas sydney viz parramatta north sydney demonstrates resident attitude towards tree depends largely tree location tree located private land preferred aesthetic functionality e g beauty privacy tree removed represent threat resident health infrastructure tree located public land appreciated people prefer live along tree lined street aesthetic environmental value tree paramount attitude vary income education dwelling type finding study suggest local government must engage effectively socio economically diverse population recognise different attitude community policy practice managing urban greenery
or_abt: Understanding people’s attitudes towards the urban forest is crucial to advance sustainability goals and for proposing policy changes in local governments. With global cities such as Sydney becoming highly multi-cultural, it is vital for local governments in cities to be responsive to the diverse voices and interests of their residents. This paper investigates attitudes of people from different socio-economic backgrounds and thereby identifies barriers and opportunities for tree planting. Analysing two socio-economically diverse local government areas (LGAs) in Sydney, viz. Parramatta and North Sydney, this paper demonstrates that residents’ attitudes towards trees depends largely on tree location. Trees located on private land, are preferred for aesthetics and functionality (e.g. beauty and privacy), and trees are removed if they represent a threat to residents’ health or infrastructure. Trees located on public land are appreciated because people prefer to live along a tree-lined street where aesthetic and environmental values of trees are paramount. The above attitudes vary with income, education and dwelling type. Findings from this study suggest that local governments must engage effectively with socio-economically diverse populations and recognise different attitudes of communities in policies and practices for managing urban greenery.

title: Impact and Return on Investment of the Take Kare Safe Space Program—A Harm Reduction Strategy Implemented in Sydney, Australia
authers: ['Christopher M. Doran', 'Phillip Wadds', 'Anthony Shakeshaft', 'Dam Anh Tran']
abstract: safe space increasingly utilized reduce alcohol related harm violence crime improve public safety nightlife setting study aimed determine impact return investment take kare safe space tkss programa harm reduction program implemented address alcohol related violence disorder three location sydney night time economy tkss ambassador provided support static safe space patrolled designated nightlife precinct provide practical assistance vulnerable intoxicated people ambassador recorded information relating interaction including client age gender perceived level intoxication time length engagement program cost program implementation benefit major incident averted obtained allow calculation return investment december april people supported tkss ambassador user male aged year intervention ambassador serious risk harm averted case program return investment estimated suggesting investment result benefit safe space extensively utilized particularly young male high level intoxication represent positive return investment despite growth service remains notable absence rigorous independent evaluation regarding outcome benefit safe space program policy perspective need high quality economic evaluation better inform decision competing us limited resource
or_abt: Safe spaces are increasingly utilized to reduce alcohol-related harm, violence, crime and improve public safety in nightlife settings. This study aimed to determine the impact and return on investment of the Take Kare Safe Space (TKSS) program—a harm reduction program implemented to address alcohol-related violence and disorder in three locations in Sydney’s night-time economy between 2014 and 2019. TKSS ambassadors provided support at static safe spaces and patrolled designated nightlife precincts to provide practical assistance to vulnerable and intoxicated people. Ambassadors recorded information relating to these interactions including ‘client’ age, gender, perceived level of intoxication, time and length of engagement with the program. Costs of program implementation and benefits of major incidents averted were obtained to allow calculation of return on investment. From December 2014 to April 2019, 66,455 people were supported by TKSS ambassadors. Most users were male (62%) and aged 18–25 years (66%). Of 3633 interventions by ambassadors, serious risk of harm was averted in 735 cases (20%). The program’s return on investment is estimated at 2.67, suggesting that a $1 investment results in $2.67 in benefits. Safe Spaces are extensively utilized, particularly by young males with high levels of intoxication, and represent a positive return on investment. Despite the growth of such services, there remains a notable absence of rigorous, independent evaluation regarding the outcomes and/or social benefit of safe space programs. From a policy perspective, there is a need for more high-quality economic evaluations to better inform decisions about competing uses of limited resources.

title: Women and new labour: Engendering politics and policy?
abstract: although growing body international feminisation politics policy process new labour term office progress rapidly growing series text around new labour politics policy text conducted new labour politics policy gendered perspective despite fact new labour set specifically address woman issue attract woman voter book fill gap interesting timely way woman new labour valuable addition feminist mainstream scholarship science particularly political science policy economics instead focusing traditionally feminist area politics policy violent crime woman author opt focus three case study area mainstream policy economic policy foreign policy welfare policy gendered perspective analytical framework provided editor yield generalisable insight outlast new labour third term
or_abt: Although there is a growing body of international literature on the feminisation of politics and the policy process and, as New Labour’s term of office progresses, a rapidly growing series of texts around New Labour’s politics and policies, until now no one text has conducted an analysis of New Labour’s politics and policies from a gendered perspective, despite the fact that New Labour have set themselves up to specifically address women’s issues and attract women voters. This book fills that gap in an interesting and timely way. Women and New Labour will be a valuable addition to both feminist and mainstream scholarship in the social sciences, particularly in political science, social policy and economics. Instead of focusing on traditionally feminist areas of politics and policy (such as violent crime against women) the authors opt to focus on three case study areas of mainstream policy (economic policy, foreign policy and welfare policy) from a gendered perspective. The analytical framework provided by the editors yields generalisable insights that will outlast New Labour’s third term.

title: Importance of sex education for a successful post-school transition: Experiences of high school girls with intellectual disability
abstract: background student intellectual disability often receive holistic sex education critical successful transition post school life including ability make healthy choice sexuality relationship aim inclusive study explore perception experience sex education australian high school girl intellectual disability prepare transition post school life method high school girl aged year participated study interview analysed using inductive content finding finding indicate critical topic gender sexual identity masturbation sufficiently covered sex education new south wale australia participating girl highlighted way teacher could make sex education lesson accessible individual learning plan meeting important platform transition planning attended le third girl study conclusion comprehensive accessible program sex education high school girl intellectual disability needed promote successful transition autonomous life student
or_abt: Background. Students with intellectual disability often do not receive holistic sex education, which is critical for their successful transition to post-school life, including having an ability to make healthy choices about their sexuality and relationships. The aim of this inclusive research study was to explore the perceptions and experiences of sex education with Australian high school girls with intellectual disability, as they prepare for a transition to post-school life. Method. There were 11 high school girls aged 13 – 20 years who participated in this study. The interviews were analysed using inductive content analysis. Findings. The findings indicate that critical topics such as gender and sexual identity, and masturbation are not sufficiently covered in sex education in New South Wales, Australia. The participating girls also highlighted ways in which teachers could make sex education lessons more accessible. Individual Learning Plan meetings, an important platform for transition planning, were attended by less than a third of the girls in this study. Conclusions. Comprehensive and accessible programs on sex education for high school girls with intellectual disability are needed to promote successful transition to an autonomous life for these students.

title: Scoping Review of Family Interventions That Support the Physical Health of Caregivers
authers: ['Abner Weng Cheong Poon', 'Julia Lappin', 'Alyssa Cassidy', 'Jan Breckenridge']
abstract: purpose family intervention developed support carers people mental illness much known intervention improve carers physical health aimed identify analyze existing family intervention addressed physical health carers method scoping conducted identify peer reviewed journal article family intervention physical health component total six article found analyzed thematically identify family intervention physical health component intervention associated physical health outcome result synthesis finding relevant article showed development physical health component family intervention emerging early stage however study physical health minor area focusing mainly stress sleep conclusion family intervention would holistic consideration physical health issue addressed core module
or_abt: Purpose Family interventions have been developed to support carers of people with mental illness, but not much is known about how such interventions can improve carers’ physical health. This review aimed to identify and analyze existing family interventions that addressed the physical health of carers. Methods A scoping review was conducted to identify peer-reviewed journal articles on family interventions with physical health components. A total of six articles were found and analyzed thematically to identify the family interventions, physical health components of the interventions, and associated physical health outcomes. Results Synthesis of the findings from relevant articles showed that the development of physical health components in family interventions is emerging and at an early stage. However, most studies had physical health as a minor area focusing mainly on stress and sleep. Conclusions Family interventions would be more holistic if consideration of physical health issues was addressed as a core module.

title: ‘Better than a pill’: digital storytelling as a narrative process for refugee women
abstract: digital storytelling valuable ethical tool engage collaborative refugee woman recount digital storytelling mixed method study settlement document journey woman entered australia woman risk program instead merely asking series question digital storytelling process extended qualitative inquiry approach valued woman memory interest hope methodology represents meaningful way engaging collaborative participating woman storyteller valued active co constructor new knowledge outline three digital narrative whole consider learn storytelling process woman complex circumstance privileged protagonist producer story argue worth critically reflecting concept woman propose meaningful way articulate life relinquish researcher role question asker enter space alongside participant listen intently highlight broader potential digital storytelling particularly mental health collaboration refugee participant
or_abt: Digital storytelling is a valuable and ethical research tool to engage in collaborative research with refugee women. This paper recounts how digital storytelling was used in a mixed-methods study on settlement, to document the journeys of women who entered Australia through the Woman at Risk program in 2014–2015. Instead of merely asking a series of questions, the digital storytelling process extended our qualitative inquiry as an approach that valued the women’s own memories, interests, and hopes. The methodology represents a meaningful way of engaging in collaborative research, where participating women were not just storytellers but valued as active co-constructors of new knowledge. We outline each of three digital narratives as a ‘whole’ to consider what we can learn from a storytelling process where women with complex circumstances are privileged as protagonists-and-producers of their own stories. We argue that it is worth critically reflecting on the concepts the women propose for themselves as meaningful ways to articulate their lives, when we relinquish the researcher role as question asker to enter a space alongside participants and listen intently. Our paper highlights the broader potential of digital storytelling particularly in mental health research in collaboration with refugee participants.

title: Artistic Representations of Refugees: What Is the Role of the Artist?
abstract: ethical consideration artist involved collaborative project refugee asylum seeker sparse indicating lack robust discussion ethical pitfall artist may encounter endeavour based first author reflection subjective experience artist representing story young somali asylum seeker woman collaborative filmmaking aim open broader discussion artist responsibility produce counter narrative value refugee perspective voice artist avoid perpetuating existing trope time detrimental refugee asylum seeker ensure artist agenda secondary protagonist wish convey suggest five simple way realising goal genuine collaboration informed consent anonymity focusing mundane case filmmaking specifically awareness editing process political act
or_abt: The literature on ethical considerations for artists involved in collaborative projects with refugees and asylum seekers is sparse, indicating a lack of robust discussions on the ethical pitfalls artists may encounter in such endeavours. Based on the first author’s reflections on her subjective experiences as an artist representing the story of a young Somali asylum seeker woman through collaborative filmmaking, this paper aims to open up broader discussions about artists’ responsibilities to produce counter-narratives that value refugees’ perspectives and voices. By doing so, artists can avoid perpetuating existing tropes that can at times be detrimental to refugees and asylum seekers, and ensure that artists’ own agendas are secondary to what ‘protagonists’ wish to convey. We suggest five simple ways of realising this goal: genuine collaboration; informed consent; anonymity; focusing on the mundane; and (in the case of filmmaking specifically) an awareness of the editing process as a political act.

title: Gendered Responses to Gendered Harms: Sexual Violence and Bystander Intervention at Australian Music Festivals
abstract: bystander intervention shown promise preventing sexual violence certain context despite emerging evidence pervasive sexual violence music festival considered bystander intervention setting drawing online conducted australian festival attendee explore role gender bystander intervention music festival finding point significant gender difference woman willing likely intervene broader range scenario argue response sexual violence collective responsibility shared woman men well festival organizer industry body
or_abt: Bystander intervention has shown promise in preventing sexual violence in certain social contexts. Despite emerging evidence of pervasive sexual violence at music festivals, no research has considered bystander intervention in this setting. Drawing on an online survey conducted with 371 Australian festival attendees, we explore the role of gender on bystander intervention at music festivals. Findings point to significant gender differences, with women more willing and likely to intervene in a broader range of scenarios. We argue that responses to sexual violence are a collective responsibility shared by both women and men, as well as festival organizers and industry bodies.

title: An emerging concern: Does social media addiction strengthen social bonds or isolating from society?
abstract: commonly believed scrolling surfing medium strengthen bonding consequence last decade medium increased popularity currently billion people different networking platform became double billion therefore ease using virtual medium communication provisionally appeared extremely useful however sociologist believe virtual interaction ushered dark era horizon evidently become rising concern medium addiction isolating user real society
or_abt: It has commonly believed that scrolling and surfing through social media strengthen social bonding. As a consequence, during the last decade, social media has increased in popularity. Currently, 3.96 billion people use different social networking platforms, which became double in 2021, which was 2.07 billion in 2015 [1]. Therefore, the ease of using these virtual media for social communication provisionally appeared extremely useful. However, sociologists believe that virtual social interaction has ushered in a dark era or that one is on the horizon[2]. Evidently, it has become a rising concern that social media addiction is isolating users from real society.

title: Rates of homicide and homicide associated with severe mental illness in NSW between 1993 and 2016

or_abt:
Objective To describe the characteristics of offenders found not guilty on the grounds of mental illness (NGMI) in New South Wales and rates of NGMI and other homicide verdicts. Method Demographic, legal and clinical data after referral to the NSW Mental Health Review Tribunal following an NGMI verdict for homicide matched with results from the National Homicide Monitoring Program. Results Between 1993 and 2016, a total of 2159 homicide offenders were dealt with by the NSW courts, including 169 (7.8%) who were found NGMI. Over this period, the rate of non-NGMI homicide convictions fell from 1.83 per 100,000 per annum to 0.65 per 100,000 per annum (Kendall’s tau = −0.79, p ⩽ 0.001) while the rate of NGMI homicide fluctuated, with an average annual rate of about 0.1 per 100,000 per annum (Kendall’s tau = 0.17, p = 0.23). There was no association between the annual rates of NGMI and non-NGMI homicides (Pearson r = −0.3, p = 0.16) but falling rate of non-NGMI homicide meant that the proportion of NGMI offences doubled from 5.5% in the first 12 years to 11% in the second 12 years. Nearly all (88.7%) of those found NGMI had a schizophrenia-related psychosis. However, there were high rates of psychiatric comorbidity including substance use disorder (60.7%) and a history of a prior head injury (41.1%). Most (83.4%) of the NGMI offenders had previous contact with mental health services, but only half of these had received treatment with antipsychotic medication. Conclusion The fall in conviction for homicide offences in the last 24 years has not been matched by a reduction in NGMI homicide verdicts. More assertive treatment of emerging psychosis and comorbid substance use disorders, and improved continui

title: Regulation of nursing professionals in Cambodia: strategies to overcome underpinning challenges

or_abt:
Aims To elucidate (i) the challenges and constraints in the development and implementation of the regulatory framework for nursing professionals in Cambodia and (ii) the specific strategies adopted to address the challenges experienced in Cambodia. Introduction The health workforce will be critical to achieving the health‐related and wider Sustainable Development Goals in the years up to 2030. Background In 2006, the countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations signed a Mutual Recognition Arrangement in relation to nursing services in the region with the main aim of facilitating the mobility of nursing professionals between countries. To ensure the competency of the health workforce and the quality and safety of health services, member states are required to establish an appropriate regulatory framework. Methods This is a qualitative descriptive study. Eighteen key informant interviews were conducted in Cambodia in 2018. Walt and Gilson’s policy analysis model was applied to organize and synthesize the data. Findings Major challenges were identified such as conceptual and cultural issues, limited capacity of Cambodian stakeholders and an unstandardized system with limited coordination. Discussion In Cambodia, the nursing regulatory environment has expanded greatly over the last decade. Strategies adopted were ‘political leadership’, optimal utilization of ‘outsider’s capacity’, strengthening ‘insider’s capacity’, and ‘dedicated consultation and collaboration and consensus building’ involving all players. Implications for nursing and health policies Policymakers in similar resource‐limited countries could apply and adapt similar strategic efforts when formulating and implementing health policies, legislation and regul
