title: Modification of physical activity on genetic effects of type 2 diabetes mellitus: a twin pairs cohort study in China
authers: ['S J Chen', 'W J Gao', 'Jinghui Lyu[...]', 'Lin Li']
abstract: explore modification effect physical activity genetic effect type diabetes mellitus dm method univariate moderation model fitted calculate modifying effect physical activity genetic effect dm based pair gender twin aged year older enrolled chinese national twin registry province city china result adjusting age gender heritability dm qualified physical activity could attenuate genetic effect dm heritability dm twin pair qualified physical activity lower twin pair without qualified physical activity model conclusion dm moderate genetic disease physical activity modify genetic effect dm
or_abt: Objective: To explore the modification effect of physical activity on the genetic effects of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Methods: The univariate moderation model was fitted to calculate the modifying effect of physical activity on the genetic effects of T2DM based on the data of 12 107 pairs of same gender twins aged 30 years and older enrolled by the Chinese National Twin Registry in 11 provinces/cities in China. Results: After adjusting for age and gender, the heritability of T2DM was 0.56 (0.31-0.84). Qualified physical activity could attenuate the genetic effects of T2DM. The heritability of T2DM in twin pairs with qualified physical activity was 0.46 (0.06-0.88), which was lower than that in twin pairs without qualified physical activity during the same model [0.68(0.36-0.94)]. Conclusion: T2DM is a moderate genetic disease, physical activity can modify the genetic effects of T2DM.

title: Chinese herbal medicine Tangshen Formula treatment for type 2 diabetic kidney disease in the early stage: Study protocol for a randomized controlled trial
abstract: background diabetic kidney disease dkd main cause end stage kidney disease become heavy economic burden due high prevalence morbidity effective strategy patient dkd diagnosed treated early preliminary study showed chinese herbal tangshen formula tsf may delay progression dkd reducing microalbuminuria macroalbuminuria improving renal function designed randomized double blind placebo controlled trial evaluate efficacy tsf patient dkd method design trial center randomized double blind placebo controlled study total participant randomized ratio experiment group tsf plus losartan control group placebo plus losartan trial cycle last week primary outcome change urine microalbumin creatinine ratio baseline week secondary outcome change rate progression clinical proteinuria period intervention rate urine microalbumin negative conversion rate normal urinary microalbumin doubling rate baseline creatinine value glomerular filtration rate group safety medication evaluated discussion hypothesize patient type diabetes early stage dkd benefit tsf successful study provide evidence based recommendation clinician trial registration clinicaltrials gov nct registered january
or_abt: Background: Diabetic kidney disease (DKD) is the main cause of end-stage kidney disease and has become a heavy economic and social burden due to its high prevalence and morbidity. The most effective strategy is that patients with DKD should be diagnosed and treated early. Preliminary studies showed that the Chinese herbal Tangshen Formula (TSF) may delay the progression of DKD, reducing microalbuminuria and macroalbuminuria and improving renal function. We designed a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of TSF in patients with DKD. Methods/design: This trial is a 13-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study. A total of 632 participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to an experiment group (TSF plus losartan) and a control group (placebo plus losartan). The trial cycle will last 24 weeks. The primary outcome will be the change in the urine microalbumin-creatinine ratio from baseline to week 24. The secondary outcome will be the change in the rate of progression to the clinical proteinuria period after intervention, the rate of urine microalbumin negative conversion, the rate of normal urinary microalbumin, the doubling rate of the baseline creatinine value and the glomerular filtration rate between the two groups. Safety in medication will also be evaluated. Discussion: We hypothesize that patients with type 2 diabetes in the early stage of DKD will benefit from TSF. If successful, this study will provide evidence-based recommendations for clinicians. Trial registration: ClinicalTrials.gov, NCT03009864. Registered January 2017.

title: Detection of Small Defects in Composite Insulators Using Terahertz Technique and Deconvolution Method
abstract: long term operation defect may occur composite insulator threat safe operation power transmission secure power transmission system would beneficial detect defect initial stage terahertz technique combined deconvolution method proposed terahertz time domain spectroscopy system built validate method proposed three type defect namely single air gap defect inclusion defect double layer air gap defect artificially prepared tested according test result found compared traditional terahertz method air gap size could lead pulse overlapping reduced mm mm deconvolution process air gap defect small mm could distinguished due shape characteristic unipolar pulse found defect damp obtained waveform near defect became smooth result present study demonstrate terahertz time domain spectroscopy thz tds combined deconvolution method high potential detection defect composite insulator
or_abt: After a long-term operation, defects may occur in the composite insulators and threat the safe operation of the power transmission. To secure the power transmission system, it would be beneficial to detect the defects in their initial stage. In this paper, the terahertz technique combined with a deconvolution method was proposed, and a terahertz time-domain spectroscopy system was built. To validate the method proposed, three types of defects, namely single air gap defect, inclusion defect, and double-layer air gap defect were artificially prepared and tested. According to the test results, it was found that, compared with the traditional terahertz method, the air gap size that could lead to pulse overlapping was reduced from 1.22 mm to 0.57 mm. After the deconvolution process, air gap defect as small as 0.173 mm could be distinguished due to the shape characteristics of unipolar pulse. It was also found that when the defect was damp, the obtained waveform near the defect became smooth. The results of the present study demonstrate that terahertz time-domain spectroscopy (THz-TDS), combined with the deconvolution method, can have high potential in the detection of defects in composite insulators.

title: Prevalence, patterns and long-term changes of multimorbidity in adults from 10 regions of China
authers: ['Z J Sun', 'J N Fan', 'C Q Yu[...]', 'Lin Li']
abstract: describe prevalence multimorbidity secular trend explore common pattern multimorbidity chinese adult method total participant attended second resurvey china kadoorie biobank ckb included study collected baseline resurvey total chronic condition included defined self reported physical examination blood sample testing multimorbidity defined co existence chronic condition pattern multimorbidity explored using hierarchical cluster result mean age participant year baseline year second resurvey prevalence multimorbidity increased year follow average number chronic condition per person increased participant increased condition per year average participant older le educated lived urban area higher prevalence multimorbidity higher increase number chronic condition increase number chronic condition higher among smoker heavy alcohol drinker common multimorbidity pattern present population consisted obesity hypertension diabetes stroke heart disease conclusion prevalence multimorbidity chinese adult increasing rapidly due ageing population population different sociodemographic background lifestyle habit may different prevalence multimorbidity change rate time
or_abt: Objective: To describe the prevalence of multimorbidity and its secular trend, and to explore the common patterns of multimorbidity in Chinese adults. Methods: A total of 25 033 participants who attended the second resurvey of China Kadoorie Biobank (CKB) were included in the study. We used data collected both at baseline (2004-2008) and at resurvey (2013-2014). A total of 13 chronic conditions were included, defined by self-reported, physical examination, and blood sample testing. Multimorbidity was defined as co-existence of two or more chronic conditions. Patterns of multimorbidity were explored using hierarchical cluster analysis. Results: The mean age of participants was (51.5±10.1) years at baseline and (59.5±10.2) years at second resurvey. The prevalence of multimorbidity increased from 33.5% to 58.1% over (8.0±0.8) years of follow-up. The average number of chronic conditions per person increased from 1.15 to 1.82 and all participants increased 0.42 conditions per 5 years on average. Participants who were older, less educated or lived in urban areas had a higher prevalence of multimorbidity and a higher increase in the number of chronic conditions. The increase in the number of chronic conditions was also higher among smokers and heavy alcohol drinkers. The most common multimorbidity pattern in the present population consisted of obesity, hypertension, diabetes, stroke, and heart disease. Conclusions: The prevalence of multimorbidity in Chinese adults is increasing rapidly due to ageing population. Populations of different sociodemographic background and lifestyle habits may have different prevalence of multimorbidity and changes in rates over time.

title: All-fiber polarization-manageable directional couplers
abstract: flexible management light polarization necessary develop technology optical fiber communication however still great challenge manipulate optical polarization fiberbased device present novel structural design three core fiber coupler create arbitrary polarization management embedding vector mode segregated core within conventional fiber coupler take advantage coupling structure achieve polarization split rotation exchange three essential polarization management fiber guided mode study coupler based coupled mode theory numerically simulation obtained result show manifest favorable operation performance management fiber modal polarization state compared previous coupler management power wavelength modal form kind fiber coupler introduces new manageable degree freedom modal polarization expected presented fiber polarization manageable directional coupler might find potential application fiber optical communication sensing system
or_abt: Flexible management of light polarization is necessary to develop the technologies of optical fiber communications. However, it is still a great challenge to manipulate optical polarization in all-fiberbased devices. Here we present a novel structural design of three-core fiber couplers to create arbitrary polarization management by embedding a vector mode segregated core within the conventional fiber couplers. We take advantages of these coupling structures to achieve polarization split, rotation, and exchange, as three essential polarization managements for fiber-guided modes. We study these couplers based on coupled-mode theory and numerically simulations. The obtained results show that they manifest favorable operation performance on management of the fiber modal polarization states. Compared to previous couplers used for management of power, wavelengths and modal forms, this kind of fiber couplers introduces a new manageable degree of freedom for modal polarization. It is expected that the presented all-fiber polarization-manageable directional couplers might find potential applications in fiber optical communications and sensing systems.

title: Breaking Chalk: the archaeological investigation of early neolithic flint mines at Long Down and Harrow Hill, West Sussex, 1984-86. The Sussex Archaeological Collections 2017. Vol. 155, 1-30.
abstract: fieldwork undertaken october september four six neolithic flint mining site west sussex recorded remains shaft drift mine flintworking area adjacent mine sample excavation site long harrow hill revealed ploughing truncated nearly surviving remains area cultivation flintwork pottery organic material retrieved excavation provided information flint artefact produced site fragment possibly carinated pottery together radiocarbon dating proved mining took place long early neolithic period bc discovery drift mine harrow hill significant open cast drift mine investigated prehistoric flint mining site southern england supplementary report found ad website
or_abt: Fieldwork undertaken between October 1984 and September 1986 at four of the six neolithic flint mining sites in West Sussex recorded the remains of shafts, drift mines and flintworking areas adjacent to the mines. Sample excavations at two of these sites, Long Down and Harrow Hill, revealed that ploughing had truncated nearly all the surviving remains in those areas under cultivation. The flintwork, pottery and organic material retrieved from the excavations provided information on the flint artefacts produced at these sites, and fragments of possibly carinated pottery, together with radiocarbon dating, proved that mining took place at Long Down in the early neolithic period (4000–3500 BC). The discovery of drift mines at Harrow Hill is significant, as they are the only open-cast or drift mines to have been investigated at a prehistoric flint mining site in southern England. A supplementary report can be found on the ADS website.

title: COVID-19 Scientific Facts vs. Conspiracy Theories: Is Science Failing to Pass Its Message?
abstract: science may failing convince significant number people covid scientific fact needed public health measure individual factor behind believing conspiracy theory adult n asked rate belief various conspiracy theory circulating medium rate psychological distress relating covid rate trust science solve covid problem rate willingness adhere measure regarding distancing quarantine finding showed conspiracy theory widely believed related lower age lower education living le densely populated area lower income stronger conspiracy theory belief predicted science mistrust unwillingness adhere public health measure psychological state strong predictor conspiracy belief recommendation stemming finding reducing belief better serving public health discussed
or_abt: Science may be failing to convince a significant number of people about COVID-19 scientific facts and needed public health measures. Individual and social factors are behind believing conspiracy theories. Adults (N = 1001) were asked to rate their beliefs in various conspiracy theories circulating in social media, rate their psychological distress relating to COVID-19, rate their trust in science to solve COVID-19 problems, and rate their willingness to adhere to measures regarding social distancing and quarantine. The findings showed conspiracy theories are widely believed and related to lower age, lower education, living in less densely populated areas, and lower income. Stronger conspiracy theory beliefs predicted science mistrust and unwillingness to adhere to public health measures. Psychological state was a strong predictor of conspiracy beliefs. Recommendations, stemming from the findings, for reducing such beliefs and better serving public health are discussed.

title: Plurality in mating: Exploring the occurrence and contingencies of mating strategies
abstract: people adopt variety strategy order achieve specific mating goal current nominated nine different mating strategy attempted estimate occurrence evidence online sample greek speaking participant indicated mixed strategy highest occurrence followed long term short term mating strategy men likely woman prefer short term mixed mating strategy younger participant likely prefer mixed long term mating strategy addition heterosexual woman sex attraction likely exclusively heterosexual woman prefer short term mixed strategy long term mating strategy furthermore found men likely woman older participant likely younger participant indicate would cheat partner long term intimate relationship furthermore heterosexual sex attraction bisexual homosexual men woman likely exclusive heterosexual participant indicate would cheat partner long term intimate relationship
or_abt: People adopt a variety of strategies in order to achieve specific mating goals. The current research nominated nine different mating strategies, and attempted to estimate their occurrence. Evidence from an online sample of 6273 Greek-speaking participants, indicated that a mixed strategy was in the highest occurrence, followed by a long-term and a short-term mating strategy. Men were more likely than women to prefer a short-term and a mixed mating strategy, and that younger participants were more likely to prefer a mixed than a long-term mating strategy. In addition, heterosexual women with same-sex attraction were more likely than exclusively heterosexual women to prefer a short-term and a mixed strategy than a long-term mating strategy. Furthermore, we found that men were more likely than women and older participants were more likely than younger participants to indicate that they would cheat on their partners if they were in a long-term intimate relationship. Furthermore , heterosexual with same-sex attraction, bisexual and homosexual men and women were more likely than exclusive heterosexual participants to indicate that they would cheat on their partners when in a long-term intimate relationship.

title: Fears of compassion magnify the harmful effects of threat of COVID-19 on mental health and social safeness across 21 countries
abstract: background covid pandemic massive global health crisis damaging consequence mental health relationship exploring factor may heighten buffer risk mental health problem context thus critical whilst compassion may protective factor contrast fear compassion increase vulnerability psychosocial distress may amplify impact pandemic mental health study explores magnifying effect fear compassion impact perceived threat covid depression anxiety stress safeness method adult participant general population n recruited across country worldwide completed self report measure perceived threat covid fear compassion self others others depression anxiety stress safeness result perceived threat covid predicted increased depression anxiety stress three flow fear compassion predicted higher level depression anxiety stress lower safeness fear compassion moderated heightened impact perceived threat covid psychological distress fear compassion others moderated effect likelihood contracting covid safeness effect consistent across country conclusion fear compassion universal magnifying effect damaging impact covid pandemic mental health safeness compassion focused intervention communication could implemented reduce resistance compassion promote mental wellbeing following pandemic
or_abt: Background: The COVID-19 pandemic is a massive global health crisis with damaging consequences to mental health and social relationships. Exploring factors that may heighten or buffer the risk of mental health problems in this context is thus critical. Whilst compassion may be a protective factor, in contrast fears of compassion increase vulnerability to psychosocial distress and may amplify the impact of the pandemic on mental health. This study explores the magnifying effects of fears of compassion on the impact of perceived threat of COVID-19 on depression, anxiety and stress, and social safeness. Methods: Adult participants from the general population (N = 4057) were recruited across 21 countries worldwide, and completed self-report measures of perceived threat of COVID-19, fears of compassion (for self, from others, for others), depression, anxiety, stress, and social safeness. Results: Perceived threat of COVID-19 predicted increased depression, anxiety and stress. The three flows of fears of compassion predicted higher levels of depression, anxiety and stress and lower social safeness. All fears of compassion moderated (heightened) the impact of perceived threat of COVID-19 on psychological distress. Only fears of compassion from others moderated the effects of likelihood of contracting COVID-19 on social safeness. These effects were consistent across all countries. Conclusions: Fears of compassion have a universal magnifying effect on the damaging impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on mental health and social safeness. Compassion focused interventions and communications could be implemented to reduce resistances to compassion and promote mental wellbeing during and following the pandemic.

title: The effect of motorcycle safety campaign on helmet use: A systematic review and meta-analysis
authers: ['Maryam Akbari', 'Kamran B Lankarani', 'Reza Tabrizi[...]', 'Mark J M Sullman']
abstract: systematic meta undertaken estimate effectiveness motorcycle safety campaign increasing helmet among motorcycle rider passenger method pubmed scopus embase web science wos database systematically searched june relevant study national institute health nih tool ass quality included study inter study heterogeneity measured using chi squared i² statistic odds ratio measure pooled effect size result record identified search eight article study eligible inclusion present meta using random effect model result meta demonstrated statistically significant increase helmet among motorcycle rider ci i² passenger ci i² finding sensitivity analysis based alternative level r imputing standard error se or showed pooled helmet among motorcycle rider r ci r ci sensitive different level r however significant effect detected pooled effect size different correlation coefficient motorcycle passenger r ci r ci increase helmet among motorcycle passenger found study monitored pre post campaign period longer year conducted thailand vietnam however effect motorcycle safe read
or_abt:
Objective This systematic review and meta-analysis was undertaken to estimate the effectiveness of motorcycle safety campaigns for increasing helmet use among motorcycle riders and passengers. Methods PubMed, Scopus, EMBASE, and the Web of Science (WOS) databases were systematically searched up June 2020 for all relevant studies. The National Institute of Health (NIH) tool was used to assess the quality of all included studies. Inter-study heterogeneity was measured using the Chi-Squared and I² statistics, with the odds ratio (OR) being used as a measure of the pooled effect size. Results Out of the 561 records identified from the literature searches, eight articles (or 11 studies) were eligible for inclusion in the present meta-analysis. Using a random effects model, the results of the meta-analysis demonstrated statistically significant increases in helmet use among motorcycle riders (OR = 4.52, 95% CI: 1.01–20.14, I² = 99.9%) and passengers (OR = 6.57, 95% CI: 1.41–30.56, I² = 99.9%). The findings of sensitivity analyses, based on alternative levels of r for imputing the standard error (SE) of the ORs, showed the pooled OR of helmet use among motorcycle riders (r = 0.7; 3.49; 95% CI: 0.78, 16.44; r = 0.9; 3.49; 95% CI: 0.76, 16.11) was sensitive to different levels of r. However, no significant effect was detected on the pooled effect size for different correlation coefficients for motorcycle passengers (r = 0.7; 6.56; 95% CI: 1.59, 27.00; r = 0.9; 6.56; 95% CI: 2.25, 19.13). Increases in helmet use among motorcycle passengers were found in studies that: monitored pre and post campaign periods for longer than one year and were conducted in Thailand or Vietnam. However, the effect of motorcycle safe

title: P610 Fear of COVID-19 among persons with Inflammatory Bowel Disease according to employment status, educational background and residential setting, as compared to persons with other gastrointestinal conditions
authers: ['Bobby Lo', 'A Mokrowiecka', 'Antonina A Mikocka-Walus[...]', 'S R Knowles']
abstract: background although several study reported impact fear relating covid several chronic illness population study focused gastrointestinal gi condition aim compare fear covid manifested people living inflammatory bowel disease ibd compared gi condition fear covid manifested across different demographic background employment status education level country residence among ibd respondent using large international sample method participant gi condition year age recruited country web based questionnaire demographic clinical psychosocial information collected relation covid pandemic adaptation scale developed ibd trindade ferreira measuring fear covid foc original item gi specific fear covid gi foc new item result participant ibd significant difference foc ibd gi condition whilst significant increase gi foc found ibd respondent mean sd v p greatest fear ibd respondent condition would get worse impact access medical support increased risk getting covid increased risk death got covid among ibd respondent person sick leave significantly general foc employed significantly gi foc compared employed respondent outside labour market figure b person living rural setting significantly mor read
or_abt:
Background Although several studies have reported the impact of fears relating to COVID-19 on several chronic illness populations, there are few studies focused on gastrointestinal (GI) conditions. The aim was to compare how fear of COVID-19 is manifested in people living with Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) compared to other GI conditions; and, how fear of COVID-19 is manifested across different demographic backgrounds (employment status, education level and country of residence) among IBD respondents using a large international sample. Methods Participants with a GI condition (≥18years of age) were recruited from 22 countries through a web-based questionnaire. Demographic, clinical, and psychosocial information was collected in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic. An adaptation of the scale developed for IBD by Trindade & Ferreira (2020) measuring fear of COVID-19 (FoC; original items 1–9) and GI specific fear of COVID-19 (GI-FoC; new items 10–14) was used. Results In 831 participants (312 IBD), there were no significant differences in FoC between IBD and other GI conditions; whilst significant increases in GI-FoC were found in IBD respondents (mean [SD]: 13.5 [5.5] vs. 10.9 [5.0], p<0.01). The greatest fears of IBD respondents were: their condition would get worse; impact on access to medical support; being at increased risk of getting COVID-19; and being at increased risk of death if they got COVID-19. Among IBD respondents, persons on sick leave had significantly more general FoC than those who were employed, and significantly more GI-FoC compared to the employed or respondents outside of the labour market (Figures 1a and 1b). title: Distance Teaching of Psychology in Europe: Challenges, Lessons Learned, and Practice Examples During the First Wave of COVID-19 Pandemic
abstract: covid pandemic affected many area life including education time designing study school college university across europe closed psychology educator expected change teaching method rather quickly study investigates coped situation technology method teach psychology distantly barrier outcome found situation participant n secondary school university teacher european country result showed participant across europe face similar challenge adopting distance teaching method technical organizational rather pedagogical despite fact found distance teaching specific psychological content challenging psychology teacher described positive aspect distance teaching example good practice lesson learned could generally implemented teaching psychology beyond pandemic situation
or_abt: COVID-19 pandemic has affected many areas of our lives including education. In the time of designing this study most schools, colleges, and universities across Europe were closed and psychology educators were expected to change their teaching methods rather quickly. This study investigates how they coped with this situation, which technology and methods they used to teach psychology distantly, and which barriers and outcomes they found in this situation. Participants were N = 660 secondary school and university teachers from 28 European countries. The results showed that the participants across Europe face similar challenges in adopting distance teaching methods, which were technical and organizational rather than pedagogical. Despite the fact they found distance teaching of specific psychological contents challenging, psychology teachers also described positive aspects of distance teaching, examples of good practice and lessons learned that could be generally implemented in the teaching of psychology beyond the pandemic situation.

title: Can't text, I'm driving -Factors influencing intentions to text while driving in the UK
authers: ['Mark J M Sullman', 'Aneta Przepiorka', 'Agata Błachnio', 'Tetiana Hill']
abstract: clear evidence using mobile phone driving dangerous however although driver generally know risky behaviour many continue handheld mobile phone driving present theory planned behaviour tpb explore psychological reason underpinning intention mobile phone driving general well send read text message driving across four different scenario convenience sampling obtain participant held valid licence drive uk driven least last six month owned mobile phone general intention mobile phone driving predicted positive attitude towards behaviour higher perceived behavioural control moreover predicting intention send read text message positive attitude consistent significant predictor surprisingly neither perceived behavioural control subjective norm significant predictor intention send read text message furthermore perception risk crashing apprehended police significant predictor intention send read text provided tpb variable present highlight need intervention target attitudinal change increase risk perception order reduce prevalence risky behaviour
or_abt: There is clear research evidence that using a mobile phone while driving is dangerous. However, although drivers generally know this is a risky behaviour, many continue to use a handheld mobile phone while driving. The present research used the Theory of Planned Behaviour (TPB) to explore the psychological reasons underpinning intentions to use a mobile phone while driving in general, as well as to send and read text messages while driving across four different scenarios. Convenience sampling was used to obtain data from 314 participants who held a valid licence to drive in the UK, had driven at least once in the last six months and owned a mobile phone. General intentions to use a mobile phone while driving were predicted by positive Attitudes towards the behaviour and higher Perceived Behavioural Control. Moreover, when predicting intentions to send and read text messages, it was positive Attitudes that was the most consistent and significant predictor. Surprisingly, neither Perceived Behavioural Control nor Subjective Norms were significant predictors of intentions to send or read text messages. Furthermore, perceptions of risk (crashing and being apprehended by the police) were significant predictors of intentions to send and read texts over and above that provided by the TPB variables. The present research highlights the need for interventions to target attitudinal change and to increase risk perceptions in order to reduce the prevalence of these risky behaviours.

title: Music in the lives of young children
abstract: growing body pointing significance engaging music potential bringing positive change area cognitive development academic performance educational motivation learning socio emotional development behaviour mental health across life course infant senior special issue music life young child target music significance young childrens life focus music education musical experience pre school child special issue comprised article written author several team co author country canada germany india israel new zealand south africa spain sweden united kingdom united state america study carried nine country australia canada germany india israel new zealand south africa united kingdom united state america
or_abt: There is a growing body of literature pointing to the significance of engaging with music, and to its potential for bringing about positive change in areas such as cognitive development, academic performance, educational motivation and learning, socio-emotional development and behaviour, and mental health – across the life course from infants through to seniors. The special issue ‘Music In The Lives Of Young Children’ targets music and its significance in young children’s lives with a focus on music education and the musical experience of pre-school children. The special issue is comprised of 11 articles that have been written by 32 authors (several teams of co-authors) from 10 countries (Canada, Germany, India, Israel, New Zealand, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, the United Kingdom, and the United States of America). These research studies were carried out in nine countries (Australia, Canada, Germany, India, Israel, New Zealand, South Africa, the United Kingdom, and the United States of America).

title: Behavioural response to illness: development and validation of a self-report measure of illness behaviour avoidance
authers: ['Inês A. Trindade', 'Helena Pinto', 'Ana Allen Gomes[...]', 'Nuno Bravo Ferreira']
abstract: robust scale capable assessing illness related experiential avoidance ea given medical condition currency lacking available measure ass ea related illness behaviour e action reaction relation feeling unwell purpose defining one state health obtaining physical emotional relief perceived actual illness study intends fill significant gap presenting development psychometric test measure ea related illness behaviour illness behaviour avoidance scale ibas total portuguese adult chronic illness participated study structure validity ibas tested exploratory factor efa n confirmatory factor cfa n reliability analysis ibas presented item unifactorial structure good global cmin df cfi tli srmr rmsea p local adjustment srws smcs presented good internal consistency αs construct discriminant validity ibas appears significant improvement previous ea measure illness context scale provide measurement whether behavioural response given condition manifestation ea
or_abt: A robust scale capable of assessing illness-related experiential avoidance (EA) in any given medical condition is currency lacking. Further, there is no available measure that assesses EA related to illness behaviours, i.e., actions and/or reactions in relation to feeling unwell that have the purpose of defining one’s state of health and obtaining physical or emotional relief from perceived or actual illness. This study intends to fill this significant gap by presenting the development and psychometric test of a measure of EA related to illness behaviour, the Illness Behaviour Avoidance Scale (IBAS). A total of 370 Portuguese adults with chronic illness participated in the study. The structure and validity of the IBAS was tested through an Exploratory Factor Analysis (EFA; n = 185), a Confirmatory Factor Analysis (CFA; n = 185), and reliability analyses. The IBAS presented a 7-item unifactorial structure, with good global (CMIN/DF = 2.08; CFI = 0.97; TLI = 0.94; SRMR = 0.04; RMSEA = 0.08, p = 0.139) and local adjustments (SRWs 0.56–0.73; SMCs 0.31–0.53). It also presented a good internal consistency (with αs = 0.82), and construct and discriminant validity. The IBAS appears to be a significant improvement from the use of previous EA measures in illness contexts. This scale can provide a measurement of whether the behavioural response to any given condition is a manifestation of EA.

title: Validation of the greek version of the body image-acceptance and action questionnaire
abstract: present study aimed examine psychometric property factorial structure greek version body image acceptance action questionnaire bi aaq bi aaq ass cognitive flexibility acceptance relative body image sample female middle high school sample n age sd college student sample n age sd cyprus completed set self reported eating related questionnaire reliability showed greek bi aaq high internal consistency good item total correlation principal component sample confirmatory factor sample supported factor solution case original bi aaq hierarchical multiple regression predicting eating disorder behavior assessed ede q weight concern wcs bi aaq score controlling bmi produced significant model accounted variance bi aaq remained significant predictor eating disorder behavior controlling bmi weight concern score greek version bi aaq questionnaire thus robust reliable instrument add previous knowledge role psychological flexibility acceptance body image eating disorder behaviour psychological difficulty
or_abt: The present study aimed to examine the psychometric properties and factorial structure of the Greek version of the Body Image-Acceptance and Action Questionnaire (BI-AAQ). The BI-AAQ assesses cognitive flexibility and acceptance relative to body image. Two samples: an all female middle and high school sample (N = 85; Age M = 17.97, SD = 2.74) and a college student sample (N = 240; Age M = 21.50; SD = 2.98) in Cyprus completed a set of self-reported eating-related questionnaires. Reliability analysis showed that the Greek BI-AAQ has high internal consistency and good item-total correlations. Principal Component Analysis (Sample 1) and Confirmatory Factor Analysis (Sample 2) supported a one-factor solution, as in the case of the original BI-AAQ. Hierarchical multiple regression predicting eating disorder behaviors (as assessed by the EDE-Q) from Weight Concerns (WCS) and BI-AAQ scores after controlling for BMI, produced a significant model, which accounted for 67% of variance. The BI-AAQ remained a significant predictor of eating disorder behaviors after controlling for BMI and weight concerns scores. The Greek version of the BI-AAQ questionnaire is thus a robust and reliable instrument. It adds to previous knowledge and research on the role of psychological flexibility and acceptance of body image in eating disorder behaviours and psychological difficulties.

title: The effectiveness of mass media campaigns in increasing the use of seat belts: A systematic review
authers: ['Maryam Akbari', 'Kamran B Lankarani', 'Reza Tabrizi[...]', 'Mark J M Sullman']
abstract: systematic meta conducted determine effectiveness mass medium campaign increasing seat belt among driver front seat passenger method systematically searched pubmed embase web science wos scopus database november june identify study investigating effect mass medium campaign seat belt quality included study assessed using national institute health nih tool chi squared test i² statistic evaluate inter study heterogeneity odds ratio measure effect size result record initially identified twenty article found appropriate current meta study rated good fair poor quality respectively meta finding using random effect model showed mass medium campaign resulted statistically significant increase seat belt usage among driver ci front seat passenger ci due presence heterogeneity i² driver i² front passenger additional analysis undertaken sensitivity analysis showed pooled or remained consistent removing study statistically significant increase seat belt among driver found mass medium campaign measurement period longer month combination enforcement activity published good quality score conclusion current meta found mass medium campaign read
or_abt:
Objective This systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to determine the effectiveness of mass media campaigns for increasing the use of seat belts among drivers and front seat passengers. Methods We systematically searched the PubMed, EMBASE, Web of Science (WOS), and Scopus databases from November 1974 until June 2020 to identify before-after studies investigating the effect of mass media campaigns on seat belt use. The quality of all included studies was assessed using the National Institute of Health (NIH) tool. Chi-Squared tests and the I² statistic were used to evaluate inter-study heterogeneity, while the odds ratio (OR) was used as a measure of effect size. Results Of the 793 records initially identified, twenty articles were found to be appropriate for the current meta-analysis. Of these, 13, 5, and 2 studies were rated as good, fair, and poor quality, respectively. The meta-analysis finding using random effects model showed that mass media campaigns resulted in statistically significant increases in seat belt usage among drivers (OR= 1.40, 95% CI: 1.18- 1.68) and front seat passengers (OR= 1.54, 95% CI: 1.31- 1.82). Due to the presence of heterogeneity (I²: 99.7% for drivers; I²: 99.1% for front passengers), additional analyses were also undertaken. Sensitivity analyses showed that the pooled ORs remained consistent after removing each study one by one. Statistically significant increases in seat belt use among drivers were found in mass media campaigns which: had measurement periods longer than 12 months, were used in combination with enforcement activities, were published after 2000, and had good quality scores. Conclusion The current meta-analysis found that mass media campaigns

title: Exploring the Relationship Between Self-Isolation and Distress Among People with Gastrointestinal Disorders During the COVID-19 Pandemic
authers: ['Antonina A Mikocka-Walus', 'Dave Skvarc', 'Manuel Barreiro de Acosta[...]', 'Simon R. Knowles']
abstract: study aimed explore association perceived isolation symptom distress people gi disorder time pandemic examine factor moderate relationship online cross sectional advertised mayseptember via patient organisation associated medium overall people female mean age year country participated significant relationship isolation psychological distress noted r p gi symptom moderated association isolation distress b p intervention targeting factor may help reduce distress people gi disorder time major stressor covid pandemic
or_abt: This study aimed to explore the association between perceived isolation and symptoms of distress in people with GI disorders at the time of the pandemic; and to examine factors which moderate this relationship. This online cross-sectional survey was advertised in May–September 2020 via patient organisations and associated social media. Overall, 831 people (82% female, mean age 49 years) from 27 countries participated. A significant relationship between social isolation and psychological distress was noted (r = .525, p < .001). GI symptoms moderated the association between isolation and distress (B = .047, t = 2.47, p = .015). Interventions targeting these factors may help to reduce distress in people with GI disorders at the time of major stressors such as the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Editorial: Small States and the ‘Corona Crisis’
abstract: covid pandemic global problem small state faced specific challenge related size economy small state tend particularly dependent open border free movement people either form tourist mobile worker crisis disrupted established pattern sphere time small state benefitted advantage small size tends related higher cohesion flexible crisis management easier tracking infection chain despite diversity small state situation corona crisis expected differ larger state aim section explore small state governance covid article focus challenge opportunity faced small state author raise question sustainability economy strong reliance certain sector emphasize importance diversification digitalisation
or_abt: While the COVID-19 pandemic has been a global problem, small states have faced specific challenges related to their size. The economies of small states tend to be particularly dependent on open borders and the free movement of people: either in the form of tourists or because of mobile workers. The crisis disrupted established patterns in both of these spheres. At the same time, small states also benefitted from advantages. Small size tends to be related to higher social cohesion, flexible crisis management and easier tracking of infection chains. Despite the diversity of small states, their situation in the 'Corona crisis' is expected to differ from that of larger states. The aim of the section is to explore the small state governance of COVID-19. The articles focus on the challenges and opportunities faced by small states. The authors raise questions about the sustainability of economies with strong reliance on certain sectors, and emphasize the importance of diversification and digitalisation.

title: European Clinical Neuropsychology: Role in Healthcare and Access to Neuropsychological Services
abstract: study analyzed aspect work clinical neuropsychologists across europe published comparison european country regarding nature clinical neuropsychologists work forty national psychological neuropsychological society approached responded seven country le neuropsychologists excluded license required practice clinical neuropsychology country clinical neuropsychologists work independently diagnostic assessment work frequently reported activity neuropsychologists work public hospital followed health center adult neuropsychology frequent area activity service public institution covered public entity combination patient fund public entity patient whereas service private institution covered patient combination patient public entity patient private entity suggest number neuropsychologists working across european country considerably low comparison medical professional result identified similar aspect neuropsychologists work despite variation term reimbursement mechanism reflecting economic healthcare difference estimate number clinical neuropsychologists suggest insufficient access neuropsychological service
or_abt: This study analyzed aspects of the work of clinical neuropsychologists across Europe. There are no published comparisons between European countries regarding the nature of clinical neuropsychologists’ work. Forty-one national psychological and neuropsychological societies were approached, of which 31 (76%) responded. Data from seven countries with less than 10 neuropsychologists were excluded. A license is required to practice clinical neuropsychology in 50% of the countries. Clinical neuropsychologists work independently in 62.5%. Diagnostic/assessment work is the most frequently reported activity (54%). Most neuropsychologists work in public hospitals, followed by health centers. Adult neuropsychology was the most frequent area of activity. Services in public institutions are covered by public entities (45.8%), or by a combination of patient funds and public entities (29.2%) and only 4.2% by the patient; whereas services in private institutions are covered by the patient (26.1%) and the combination of patient, public entities (21.7%) or patient and private entities (17.4%). The data suggest that the number of neuropsychologists working across European countries is considerably low in comparison to other medical professionals. The results of the survey identified similar aspects of neuropsychologists’ work, despite variations in terms of reimbursement and mechanisms, reflecting economic and healthcare differences. Estimates on the number of clinical neuropsychologists suggest insufficient access to neuropsychological services.

title: Eating disorders among middle-school students: The role of psychological inflexibility and self-esteem
abstract: cross sectional study aim shed light relation self esteem eating disorder ed part prevention effort testing mediating role psychological inflexibility sample young teenager four hundred eighteen greek speaking student representative public middle school cyprus male female mage sd screened ed pathology using eating attitude questionnaire eat completed rosenberg self esteem scale rse avoidance fusion questionnaire youth afq screening part school wide psychoeducational campaign titled love body young teen aimed raise awareness healthy body image ed within school community correlation bootstrapping mediation analysis conducted evaluate relation ed pathology self esteem psychological inflexibility mediation analysis result showed psychological inflexibility partly mediates relationship self esteem ed pathology preliminary finding highlight contribution individual negative internal event meta response event development ed lay foundation delivery informed psychological prevention effort school aiming increase psychological flexibility among student
or_abt: This cross-sectional study aims to shed further light on the relation between self-esteem and Eating Disorders (EDs) as part of prevention efforts by testing the mediating role of psychological inflexibility in a sample of young teenagers. Four hundred and eighteen Greek-speaking students from one representative public middle school in Cyprus (43.90% males and 56.10% females; Mage = 13.71, SD = 1.00) were screened for ED pathology using the Eating Attitudes Questionnaire-26 (EAT-26) and completed the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSE) and the Avoidance and Fusion Questionnaire for Youth (AFQ-Y8). Screening was part of a school-wide psychoeducational Campaign titled “Love Your Body-Young Teens”, which aimed to raise awareness on healthy body image and EDs within the school community. Correlations and bootstrapping mediation analyses were conducted to evaluate the relations between ED pathology, self-esteem, and psychological inflexibility. Mediation analyses results showed that psychological inflexibility partly mediates the relationship between self-esteem and ED pathology. These preliminary findings highlight the contributions of both the individual’s negative internal events and their meta-response to these events in the development of EDs. It lays the foundation for the delivery of research-informed psychological prevention efforts in the schools, aiming to increase psychological flexibility among students.

title: COVID-19 Unmasked Global Collaboration Protocol: longitudinal cohort study examining mental health of young children and caregivers during the pandemic
authers: ['Alexandra C De Young', 'Mira Vasileva', 'Joanna Boruszak - Kiziukiewicz[...]', 'Chrysanthi Lioupi']
abstract: background early empirical show school aged child adolescent adult experiencing elevated level anxiety depression covid pandemic currently little mental health outcome young child objective describe formation global collaboration entitled covid unmasked collaborating researcher aim describe compare covid related experience within across country examine mental health outcome young child year caregiver month period covid pandemic explore trajectory time course psychological outcome child parent period identify risk protective factor different mental health trajectory combined participating country large open access cross cultural dataset facilitate international collaboration joint publication method covid unmasked online prospective longitudinal cohort study international steering committee formed aim starting global collaboration currently partnership formed country australia cyprus greece netherlands poland spain turkey uk united state america partner started start collection caregiver young child aged year old baseline month month month caregiver invited complete online covid related exposure experience child wellbeing mental health parenting primary study outcome child mental health assessed read
or_abt:
Background Early empirical data shows that school-aged children, adolescents and adults are experiencing elevated levels of anxiety and depression during the COVID-19 pandemic. Currently, there is very little research on mental health outcomes for young children. Objectives To describe the formation of a global collaboration entitled, ‘COVID-19 Unmasked’. The collaborating researchers aim to (1) describe and compare the COVID-19 related experiences within and across countries; (2) examine mental health outcomes for young children (1 to 5 years) and caregivers over a 12-month period during the COVID-19 pandemic; (3) explore the trajectories/time course of psychological outcomes of the children and parents over this period and (4) identify the risk and protective factors for different mental health trajectories. Data will be combined from all participating countries into one large open access cross-cultural dataset to facilitate further international collaborations and joint publications. Methods COVID-19 Unmasked is an online prospective longitudinal cohort study. An international steering committee was formed with the aim of starting a global collaboration. Currently, partnerships have been formed with 9 countries (Australia, Cyprus, Greece, the Netherlands, Poland, Spain, Turkey, the UK, and the United States of America). Research partners have started to start data collection with caregivers of young children aged 1–5 years old at baseline, 3-months, 6-months, and 12-months. Caregivers are invited to complete an online survey about COVID-19 related exposure and experiences, child’s wellbeing, their own mental health, and parenting. Data analysis Primary study outcomes will be child mental health as assessed

title: How SARS-CoV-2 might affect potassium balance via impairing epithelial sodium channels?
authers: ['Maryam Noori', 'Seyed Aria Nejadghaderi', 'Mark J M Sullman[...]', 'Saeid Safiri']
abstract: severe acute respiratory syndrome coronaviruses sars cov causative agent current coronavirus disease covid pandemic electrolyte disorder particularly potassium abnormality repeatedly reported common clinical manifestation covid discus sars cov may affect potassium balance impairing activity epithelial sodium channel enac first hypothesis could justify incidence hypokalemia sars cov cell entry angiotensin converting enzyme ace may enhance activity reninangiotensinaldosterone system raas classical axis leading production aldosterone aldosterone capable enhancing activity enac resulting potassium loss epithelial cell however type ii transmembrane serine protease tmprss able inhibit enac utilized case sars cov cell entry therefore enac remains activated second hypothesis describe incidence hyperkalemia based key role furin furin necessary cleaving sars cov spike protein enac subunit furin hijacked virus decreased activity enac would expected cause retention potassium ion hyperkalemia given occurrence hypokalemia higher hyperkalemia covid patient first hypothesis may greater impact potassium level investigation warranted determine exact role enac sars cov pathogenesis
or_abt: Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronaviruses 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is the causative agent of current coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic. Electrolyte disorders particularly potassium abnormalities have been repeatedly reported as common clinical manifestations of COVID-19. Here, we discuss how SARS-CoV-2 may affect potassium balance by impairing the activity of epithelial sodium channels (ENaC). The first hypothesis could justify the incidence of hypokalemia. SARS-CoV-2 cell entry through angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) may enhance the activity of renin–angiotensin–aldosterone system (RAAS) classical axis and further leading to over production of aldosterone. Aldosterone is capable of enhancing the activity of ENaC and resulting in potassium loss from epithelial cells. However, type II transmembrane serine protease (TMPRSS2) is able to inhibit the ENaC, but it is utilized in the case of SARS-CoV-2 cell entry, therefore the ENaC remains activated. The second hypothesis describe the incidence of hyperkalemia based on the key role of furin. Furin is necessary for cleaving both SARS-CoV-2 spike protein and ENaC subunits. While the furin is hijacked by the virus, the decreased activity of ENaC would be expected, which causes retention of potassium ions and hyperkalemia. Given that the occurrence of hypokalemia is higher than hyperkalemia in COVID-19 patients, the first hypothesis may have greater impact on potassium levels. Further investigations are warranted to determine the exact role of ENaC in SARS-CoV-2 pathogenesis.

title: Understanding performance anxiety in the adolescent musician
abstract: musical performance anxiety far mainly focused adult professional musician additionally study mostly maintained clinical approach musical performance anxiety focusing diagnosis assessment treatment maladaptive performance anxiety effect selected group musician aim thesis fill gap exploring experience musical performance anxiety perspective adolescent musician student aged attending junior conservatoire youth orchestra uk cyprus responded self report questionnaire questionnaire dealt range learning performance issue yielded quantitative qualitative performance anxiety measured adolescent musician performance anxiety scale ampas designed specifically need study result revealed performance anxiety issue significant percentage student difference performance anxiety level intensity related nationality gender age susceptibility experiencing performance anxiety task efficacy quality performance environment important factor determining intensity experienced performance anxiety performance anxiety found multi faceted construct influenced variety factor relating self perception situational parameter identity culture family environment student attainment influenced performance anxiety achievement higher grade related experience higher level performance anxiety perception receiving positive feedback read
or_abt:
Research in musical performance anxiety so far has mainly focused on adult professional musicians. Additionally, studies have mostly maintained a `clinical approach' to musical performance anxiety, focusing on the diagnosis, assessment and treatment of maladaptive performance anxiety and its effects on selected groups of musicians. The aim of this thesis was to fill some of these gaps by exploring the experience of musical performance anxiety from the perspective of adolescent musicians. 410 students aged 12-19, all attending junior conservatoires and / or youth orchestras in the UK and Cyprus, responded to a self-report questionnaire. The questionnaire dealt with a range of learning and performance issues and yielded both quantitative and qualitative data. Performance anxiety was measured with the Adolescent Musicians' Performance Anxiety Scale (AMPAS), designed specifically for the needs of this study. Results revealed that performance anxiety was an issue for a significant percentage of students. Differences in performance anxiety level intensity were related to nationality and gender, but not to age. Susceptibility to experiencing performance anxiety, task efficacy and quality of performance environment were important factors in determining the intensity of experienced performance anxiety. Performance anxiety was found to be a multi-faceted construct, influenced by a variety of factors relating to self-perceptions, situational parameters, identity and culture, and family environment. Student attainment was influenced by performance anxiety. Achievement of higher Grades was related to the experience of higher levels of performance anxiety and perceptions of receiving positive feedback were
… Read more

title: Amazon Island: Revisiting Female Intimacy in Luz María Umpierre-Herrera's The Margarita Poems
abstract: zackheos argues umpierre herrera poetry collection call forth female affiliation queerly combat multiple oppression process recuperatively revise puerto rican metanarrative subordination self determination situates argument within current conversation affect postcolonial form resistance queer diasporic subjectivity transnational connection latino culture showcase representation intimacy way address notion home identity belonging
or_abt: Zackheos argues that Umpierre-Herrera's poetry collection calls forth a female affiliation, which can queerly combat multiple social oppressions and in the process also recuperatively revise a Puerto Rican metanarrative of subordination to one of self-determination. She situates her argument within current conversations about affect, postcolonial forms of resistance, queer and diasporic subjectivities, and transnational connections in Latino cultures. The chapter showcases the representation of intimacy and the ways in which it addresses notions of home, identity, and belonging.

title: Driver Aggression and Anger
abstract: aggressive driving global road safety issue aggressive driving recognized substantial contributor motor vehicle crash ranked leading concern motorist estimate show driver aggressive time odds crashing aggressive nevertheless aggressive driving receives le attention driver behavior distraction impaired driving despite comparable higher odds crash involvement likely due number different reason including confusion anger aggression inconsistent definition aggressive driving uncertainty whether road rage form part aggressive driving
or_abt: Aggressive driving is a global road safety issue. Aggressive driving is recognized as being a substantial contributor to motor vehicle crashes and is ranked as one of the leading concerns for motorists. Estimates show that drivers, when aggressive, have 35 times the odds of crashing than when not aggressive. Nevertheless, aggressive driving receives less research attention than other driver behaviors, such as distraction or impaired driving, despite having comparable or higher odds of crash involvement. This is likely to be due to a number of different reasons, including a confusion between anger and aggression, inconsistent definitions for aggressive driving, and uncertainty over whether road rage forms a part of aggressive driving.

title: The Avoidance and Fusion Questionnaire for Youths AFQ-Y8 Validation in Greek-speaking adolescents
abstract: current study evaluates whether avoidance fusion questionnaire youth afq suitable measuring psychological inflexibility greek speaking adolescent n based previous underlying theory acceptance commitment therapy act initial item scale afq converged short item scale youth greco lambert baer short version afq questionnaire afq afq adapted greek administered high school student mean age sd context larger study result merged examine questionnaire psychometric property exploratory factor principal component extraction oblique rotation revealed single factor accounting variability reliability showed cronbachs alpha coefficient factor next step ensure afq correlated theoretically expected outcome concurrent predictive validity thus result presented explanation predictive convergent validity testing afq related unrelated measure based result afq appears adequate internal consistency greek speaking population conclusion greek afq useful tool evaluating psychological inflexibility group based adolescent theoretical clinical implication discussed
or_abt: The current study evaluates whether the Avoidance and Fusion Questionnaire for Youth (AFQ-Y8) is suitable for measuring psychological inflexibility in Greek speaking adolescents (N=1019). Based on previous underlying theory of Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT), the initial 50-item scale of AFQ converged into a short 8-item scale for youth (Greco, Lambert, & Baer 2008). The short version of the AFQ questionnaire (AFQ-Y8) was used. The AFQ was adapted in Greek and administered to high school students (mean age=14.79, SD=1.058) in the context of two larger studies from which results were merged to examine the questionnaires’ psychometric properties. An exploratory factor analysis with principal components extraction and an oblique rotation revealed a single factor accounting for 43.08% of the variability. A reliability analysis showed a Cronbach’s alpha coefficient of .81 for the factor. The next step was to ensure that the AFQ-Y8 is correlated with theoretically expected outcomes (concurrent and predictive validity), thus, results will be presented as an explanation for its predictive and convergent validity testing the AFQ-Y8 with related and unrelated measures. Based on the results, AFQ-Y8 appears to have adequate internal consistency in the Greek speaking population. In conclusion, the Greek AFQ-Y8 is a useful tool in evaluating psychological inflexibility and for group-based research in adolescents. Theoretical and clinical implications will be discussed.

title: ARISTOTLE'S VISION OF POLITICAL EUDAIMONIA QUA THE DIVINE IN ETHICA NIKOMACHEA

or_abt:
This paper firstly explores Aristotle's moral vision of eudaimonia or 'happiness' in Ethica Nichomachea (EN). The ensuing discussion points out that the life of excellence (arête) in all classical Greek philosophy culminates in the attainment of eudemonic being, equivocating likeness to the divine to the highest possible degree. The paper goes on to disclose significant differences concerning happiness between the moral and political philosophy of Aristotle and that of his predecessors, Socrates, and Plato. In turn, the present inquiry explores Aristotle's claim in EN that the education of a sufficient number of citizens of superior refinement best accomplishes human flourishing in both the private and public spheres. According to Aristotle, the paramount achievement of eudaimonia in individuals and the city-state happens through the moral and intellectual education of citizens of refinement in political science (politike episteme). Consequently, the present exploration carefully investigates the crux of Aristotle's vision of educating citizens of quality as this aspect of his ethics best illumines the holistic aim scope and curriculum of his proposed study in politike episteme (the science integrating all sciences). Finally, the present endeavor explores the superiority that Aristotle allots to contemplative or divine theoria in the latter part of his ethical treatise (Book X.7-8), where, he establishes a hierarchy between phrõnesis (practical wisdom) and theoria (contemplative wisdom), ascertaining the higher standing of the latter, a claim that inevitably leads him into paradox. Nevertheless, he also considers that perhaps contemplative wisdom surpasses divine reason, therefore, any form of duality between 'lower' an

title: The impact of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic on individuals with gastrointestinal disorders: A protocol of an international collaborative study
authers: ['Nuno Bravo Ferreira', 'Antonina A Mikocka-Walus', 'Miranda A L Van Tilburg[...]', 'Simon R. Knowles']
abstract: covid pandemic significant impact mental health across globe people living chronic gastrointestinal gi disorder might particularly risk mental health complication given higher rate comorbid anxiety depression compared healthy population gi disorder affect population worldwide international collaborative study seek evaluate extent impact covid pandemic gi symptom specifically generally well living chronic gi condition method longitudinal three time point baseline month month conducted online adult participant gi disorder multiple country recruited via patient association medium advertising utilizing snowball sampling participant invited complete battery questionnaire including demographic health parameter measure gastrointestinal symptom fear covid perceived impact covid illness perception coping depression anxiety stress catastrophizing quality life using validated measure available statistical analysis include univariate descriptive model multivariate model utilizing regression mediation moderation latent growth model conclusion project may present novel information field psychogastroenterology may provide crucial information regarding area impact individual gi disorder following pandemic information guide healthcare provider patient association target support related pandemic mental read
or_abt:
Objective: The COVID-19 pandemic has had a significant impact on mental health across the globe. People living with a chronic gastrointestinal (GI) disorder might be particularly at risk of mental health complications given higher rates of comorbid anxiety and depression compared to the healthy population. As GI disorders affect up to 40% of the population worldwide, this international collaborative study seeks to evaluate the extent of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on GI symptoms specifically and more generally on the well-being of those living with chronic GI conditions. Methods: A longitudinal survey with three time points (baseline, 6-month, and 12-month) will be conducted online. Adult participants with GI disorders from multiple countries will be recruited via patient associations, social media advertising, utilizing snowball sampling. Participants will be invited to complete a battery of questionnaires including demographic and health parameters, and measures of gastrointestinal symptoms, fear of COVID-19, perceived impact of COVID-19, illness perceptions, coping, depression, anxiety, stress, catastrophizing, and quality of life, using validated measures where available. Statistical analyses will include univariate descriptive models, multivariate models utilizing regression, mediation, and moderation, and latent growth models. Conclusions: This project may present novel information to the field of psychogastroenterology and may provide crucial information regarding the areas of impact for individuals with GI disorders during and following the pandemic. Further, this information can guide healthcare providers and patient associations on how to target support related to the pandemic mental he

title: Burden of ischemic heart disease and its attributable risk factors in 204 countries and territories, 1990–2019
abstract: aim report prevalence death disability adjusted life year dalys associated ischemic heart disease ihd attributable risk factor country territory age sex socio demographic index sdi method result ischemic heart disease defined acute myocardial infarction mi chronic ihd angina asymptomatic ihd following mi cause death ensemble modelling produce fatality estimate prevalence non fatal sequalae ihd estimated using dismod mr estimate presented count age standardized rate per population ihd accounted million prevalent case million death million dalys worldwide decrease global age standardized prevalence rate ihd death dalys global prevalence death rate ihd higher among male across age group death rate peaked oldest group sex negative association found age standardized daly rate sdi globally high systolic blood pressure high low density lipoprotein cholesterol smoking three largest contributor dalys attributable ihd conclusion although global age standardized prevalence death daly rate decreased prevention control programme implemented reduce population exposure risk factor reduce risk ihd high risk population provide appropriate care community
or_abt: Aims To report the prevalence, deaths, and disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) associated with ischemic heart disease (IHD) and its attributable risk factors in 204 countries and territories from 1990 to 2019, by age, sex, and socio-demographic index (SDI). Methods and results Ischemic heart disease was defined as acute myocardial infarction (MI) and chronic IHD (angina; asymptomatic IHD following MI). Cause of death ensemble modelling was used to produce fatality estimates. The prevalence of the non-fatal sequalae of IHD was estimated using DisMod MR 2.1. All estimates were presented as counts and age-standardized rates per 100 000 population. In 2019, IHD accounted for 197.2 million (177.7–219.5) prevalent cases, 9.1 million (8.4–9.7) deaths, and 182.0 million (170.2–193.5) DALYs worldwide. There were decreases in the global age-standardized prevalence rates of IHD [−4.6% (−5.7, −3.6)], deaths [−30.8% (−34.8, −27.2)], and DALYs [−28.6% (−33.3, −24.2)] from 1990 to 2019. In 2019, the global prevalence and death rates of IHD were higher among males across all age groups, while the death rate peaked in the oldest group for both sexes. A negative association was found between the age-standardized DALY rates and SDI. Globally, high systolic blood pressure (54.6%), high low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (46.6%), and smoking (23.9%) were the three largest contributors to the DALYs attributable to IHD. Conclusion Although the global age-standardized prevalence, death, and DALY rates all decreased. Prevention and control programmes should be implemented to reduce population exposure to risk factors, reduce the risk of IHD in high-risk populations, and provide appropriate care for communities.

title: The LIFEwithIBD Intervention: Study Protocol for a Randomized Controlled Trial of a Face-to-Face Acceptance and Commitment Therapy and Compassion-Based Intervention Tailored to People With Inflammatory Bowel Disease
abstract: background ample evidence high mental health burden caused inflammatory bowel disease ibd several construct experiential avoidance cognitive fusion shame self criticism recently emerged potential intervention target improve mental health ibd psychotherapeutic model acceptance commitment therapy compassion based intervention known target construct protocol aim describe arm randomized controlled trial rct testing efficacy act compassion focused intervention named living intention fullness engagement inflammatory bowel disease lifewithibd intervention treatment usual tau v tau improving psychological distress quality life work functioning ibd symptom perception illness related shame psychological flexibility self compassion disease activity inflammation biomarkers gut microbiota diversity method trial registered clinicaltrials gov identifier nct date assigned lifewithibd intervention adaptation ibd population mind programme people cancer acceptance mindfulness compassion based intervention designed delivered group format lifewithibd intervention structure topic presented protocol participant recruited gastroenterology service coimbra university hospital june september patient screened participant selected randomly assigned condition experimental group lifewithibd tau control group tau completed ba read
or_abt:
Background: There is ample evidence of the high mental health burden caused by Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD). Several constructs such as experiential avoidance, cognitive fusion, shame, and self-criticism have recently emerged as potential intervention targets to improve mental health in IBD. Psychotherapeutic models such as Acceptance and Commitment Therapy and compassion-based interventions are known to target these constructs. In this protocol, we aim to describe a two-arm Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) testing the efficacy of an ACT and compassion-focused intervention named Living with Intention, Fullness, and Engagement with Inflammatory Bowel Disease (LIFEwithIBD) intervention + Treatment As Usual (TAU) vs. TAU in improving psychological distress, quality of life, work and social functioning, IBD symptom perception, illness-related shame, psychological flexibility, self-compassion, disease activity, inflammation biomarkers, and gut microbiota diversity. Methods: This trial is registered at ClinicalTrials.gov (Identifier: NCT03840707, date assigned 13/02/2019). The LIFEwithIBD intervention is an adaptation to the IBD population of the Mind programme for people with cancer, an acceptance, mindfulness, and compassion-based intervention designed to be delivered in a group format. The LIFEwithIBD intervention's structure and topics are presented in this protocol. Participants were recruited at the Gastroenterology Service of the Coimbra University Hospital between June and September 2019. Of the 355 patients screened, 61 participants were selected, randomly assigned to one of two conditions [experimental group (LIFEwithIBD + TAU) or control group (TAU)] and completed the ba
