title: How People Become Attractive to Prospective Mates: Strategies of Self- Promotion in the Greek Cultural Context
abstract: important aspect human mating appeal prospective mate accordingly current attempted identify strategy people order become attractive prospective intimate partner specifically using open ended questionnaire sample greek speaking participant identified act people performed order become attractive mate using quantitative method sample greek speaking participant classified act different strategy found enhancing look becoming pleasant among preferred strategy woman likely men adopt strategy involved look men likely woman adopt strategy involved resource acquisition capacity moreover age effect found strategy identified strategy classified broader domain aiming develop demonstrate fitness increasing quality deceive fitness impairing trait
or_abt: An important aspect of human mating is to appeal to prospective mates. Accordingly, the current research attempted to identify the strategies that people use in order to become more attractive as prospective intimate partners. More specifically, using open-ended questionnaires in a sample of 326 Greek-speaking participants, we identified 87 acts that people performed in order to become more attractive as mates. By using quantitative research methods in a sample of 2,197 Greek-speaking participants, we classified these acts into 16 different strategies. We found that, enhancing one's looks and becoming more pleasant, were among the most preferred strategies. Women were more likely than men to adopt strategies that involved looks, while men were more likely than women to adopt strategies that involved resource acquisition capacity. Moreover, age effects were found for most strategies. The identified strategies were classified into two broader domains, one aiming to develop and demonstrate fitness-increasing qualities, and the other to deceive about fitness-impairing traits.

title: Patterns of Psychological Responses among the Public during the Early Phase of COVID-19: A Cross-Regional Analysis
authers: ['Yuen Yu Chong', 'Wai Tong Chien', 'Ho Yu Cheng[...]', 'Angelos P. Kassianos']
abstract: study aimed compare mediation psychological flexibility prosociality coping impact illness perception toward covid mental health among seven region convenience sampled online conducted april june citizen country illness perception toward covid psychological flexibility prosociality coping mental health socio demographic lockdown related variable covid status assessed result showed psychological flexibility significant mediator relationship illness perception toward covid mental health across region p seeking support significant mediator across subgroup p range except hong kong sample p north south american sample p mediation found problem solving except northern european sample p prosociality significant mediator hong kong sample p eastern european sample p finding indicate fostering psychological flexibility may help mitigate adverse mental impact covid across region role seeking support problem solving prosociality vary across region
or_abt: This study aimed to compare the mediation of psychological flexibility, prosociality and coping in the impacts of illness perceptions toward COVID-19 on mental health among seven regions. Convenience sampled online survey was conducted between April and June 2020 from 9130 citizens in 21 countries. Illness perceptions toward COVID-19, psychological flexibility, prosociality, coping and mental health, socio-demographics, lockdown-related variables and COVID-19 status were assessed. Results showed that psychological flexibility was the only significant mediator in the relationship between illness perceptions toward COVID-19 and mental health across all regions (all ps = 0.001–0.021). Seeking social support was the significant mediator across subgroups (all ps range = <0.001–0.005) except from the Hong Kong sample (p = 0.06) and the North and South American sample (p = 0.53). No mediation was found for problem-solving (except from the Northern European sample, p = 0.009). Prosociality was the significant mediator in the Hong Kong sample (p =0.016) and the Eastern European sample (p = 0.008). These findings indicate that fostering psychological flexibility may help to mitigate the adverse mental impacts of COVID-19 across regions. Roles of seeking social support, problem-solving and prosociality vary across regions.

title: Typologies of Adolescent Musicians and Experiences of Performance Anxiety Among Instrumental Learners
abstract: suggests music performance anxiety mpa prevalent adolescence developmental period increased likelihood experiencing anxiety evaluative condition evidence indicate individual may respond evaluative situation distinct way factor contributing individuality response evaluative situation test taking musical performance yet fully understood study investigated student typology adolescent instrumental learner participant included learner completed young musician performance questionnaire k mean cluster revealed three typology cluster moderately anxious student evidencing lower level motivation feeling ineffective guarding self esteem cluster highly anxious student evidencing negative self perception susceptible experiencing maladaptive mpa cluster low anxious student evidencing high level motivation confidence inclined toward experiencing adaptive mpa cluster solution effectiveness validated discriminant significant association examination achievement cluster membership revealed variation cluster thematic qualitative facilitated understanding characteristic study add body mpa exploring different way adolescent musician interpret respond anxiety inducing situation finding implication clinical educational practice
or_abt: Literature suggests that music performance anxiety (MPA) is prevalent in adolescence, a developmental period with increased likelihood of experiencing anxiety under evaluative conditions. Evidence also indicate that individuals may respond to evaluative situations in distinct ways. Factors contributing to the individuality of responses in evaluative situations (such as test taking and musical performance) are not yet fully understood. This study investigated student typologies in adolescent instrumental learners. Participants included 410 learners who completed the Young Musicians’ Performance Questionnaire. K-Means cluster analysis revealed three typologies: Cluster 1 – moderately anxious students evidencing lower levels of motivation and feeling ineffective but guarding their self-esteem; Cluster 2 – highly anxious students evidencing negative self-perceptions and being susceptible to experiencing maladaptive MPA; Cluster 3 – low anxious students evidencing high levels of motivation and confidence and inclined toward experiencing adaptive MPA. The 3-cluster solution effectiveness was validated with discriminant analysis. Significant associations between examination achievement and cluster membership revealed variations between clusters. Thematic analysis of qualitative data facilitated further understanding of their characteristics. This study adds to the body of MPA literature by exploring the different ways with which adolescent musicians interpret and respond to anxiety inducing situations. Findings have implications for clinical and educational practice.

title: Attitudes Toward Four Levels of Self-Driving Technology Among Elderly Drivers
abstract: automatization autonomous vehicle drastically improve elderly driver safety mobility lower cost driver environment autonomous vehicle technology developing rapidly much le attention resource devoted understanding acceptance attitude preference vehicle automatization among driver group elderly study elderly driver year evaluated four vehicle representing sae level term safety trustworthiness enjoyment reliability comfort ease attractiveness well reporting preference vehicle employing four level automation result repeated measure anova showed elderly driver rated sae level vehicle highest fully automated vehicle sae lowest across attribute preference vehicle declined function increasing automatization seven attribute formed internally coherent attitude automatization scale strong correlate vehicle preference age annual mileage related attitude preference automated vehicle current study show elderly driver attitude toward automatization studied result taken account developing automated vehicle full potential automatization may realized elderly driver ignored
or_abt: Automatization and autonomous vehicles can drastically improve elderly drivers' safety and mobility, with lower costs to the driver and the environment. While autonomous vehicle technology is developing rapidly, much less attention and resources have been devoted to understanding the acceptance, attitudes, and preferences of vehicle automatization among driver groups, such as the elderly. In this study, 236 elderly drivers (≥65 years) evaluated four vehicles representing SAE levels 2–5 in terms of safety, trustworthiness, enjoyment, reliability, comfort, ease of use, and attractiveness, as well as reporting preferences for vehicles employing each of the four levels of automation. The results of a repeated-measures ANOVA showed that the elderly drivers rated the SAE level 2 vehicle highest and the fully automated vehicle (SAE 5) lowest across all attributes. The preference for the vehicle declined as a function of increasing automatization. The seven attributes formed an internally coherent “attitude to automatization” scale, a strong correlate of vehicle preference. Age or annual mileage were not related to attitudes or preferences for automated vehicles. The current study shows that elderly drivers' attitudes toward automatization should be studied further, and these results should be taken into account when developing automated vehicles. The full potential of automatization may not be realized if elderly drivers are ignored.

title: Impact of COVID-19 pandemic on mental health: An international study
abstract: background covid pandemic triggered vast governmental lockdown impact lockdown mental health inadequately understood hand drastic change daily routine could detrimental mental health hand might experienced negatively especially entire population affected method aim study determine mental health outcome pandemic induced lockdown examine known predictor mental health outcome therefore surveyed n people country language outcome assessed stress depression affect wellbeing predictor included country sociodemographic factor lockdown characteristic factor psychological factor result result indicated average sample languishing low level mental health moderate mental health importantly three consistent predictor mental health emerged support education level psychologically flexible v rigid responding poorer outcome strongly predicted worsening finance access basic supply conclusion result suggest whole respondent moderately mentally healthy time population wide lockdown highest level mental health difficulty found approximately population finding suggest public health initiative target people without support whose finance worsen result lockdown intervention promote psychological flexibility may mitigate impact pandemic
or_abt: Background The COVID-19 pandemic triggered vast governmental lockdowns. The impact of these lockdowns on mental health is inadequately understood. On the one hand such drastic changes in daily routines could be detrimental to mental health. On the other hand, it might not be experienced negatively, especially because the entire population was affected. Methods The aim of this study was to determine mental health outcomes during pandemic induced lockdowns and to examine known predictors of mental health outcomes. We therefore surveyed n = 9,565 people from 78 countries and 18 languages. Outcomes assessed were stress, depression, affect, and wellbeing. Predictors included country, sociodemographic factors, lockdown characteristics, social factors, and psychological factors. Results Results indicated that on average about 10% of the sample was languishing from low levels of mental health and about 50% had only moderate mental health. Importantly, three consistent predictors of mental health emerged: social support, education level, and psychologically flexible (vs. rigid) responding. Poorer outcomes were most strongly predicted by a worsening of finances and not having access to basic supplies. Conclusions These results suggest that on whole, respondents were moderately mentally healthy at the time of a population-wide lockdown. The highest level of mental health difficulties were found in approximately 10% of the population. Findings suggest that public health initiatives should target people without social support and those whose finances worsen as a result of the lockdown. Interventions that promote psychological flexibility may mitigate the impact of the pandemic.

title: ‘Educating for peace’: conflict, division and social work education in Cyprus
abstract: work practice training context political ethnic conflict seen renewed interest among scholar recent tried shift focus away simplistic interpretation work unshakably benevolent profession recent emphasis work colonial legacy structural cause political violence provide u important new direction rethink reshape work education practice context cyprus present interesting yet explored case study remains island de facto divided along ethnic line division resulted physical political separation populous ethnic community greek cypriot turkish cypriot united nation un sponsored peace talk gained momentum recent year offer first systematic exploration view work student across side divide mixed method approach student able express thought belief work post conflict reality study confirms contradictory nature work education cyprus challenge futility nationalism argues importance bi communal work partnership
or_abt: Social work practice and training in the context of political and ethnic conflict has seen renewed interest among scholars. Recent research has tried to shift focus away from simplistic interpretations of social work as an unshakably ‘benevolent’ profession. A recent emphasis on social work’s colonial legacies and the structural causes of political violence provide us with important new directions on how to rethink and reshape social work education and practice in these contexts. Cyprus presents a very interesting, yet under-explored, case study as it remains an island de facto divided, along ethnic lines. The division has resulted in the physical and political separation of the two most populous ethnic communities (Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots). United Nations (UN)-sponsored peace talks have gained momentum in recent years. This paper offers the first systematic exploration of the views of social work students across both sides of the divide. Through a mixed-method approach, students were able to express their thoughts and beliefs on ‘the other’ and on social work in the post-conflict realities. The study confirms the contradictory nature of social work education in Cyprus challenges the futility of nationalism and argues for the importance of bi-communal social work partnerships.

title: Nicosia’s Queer Art Subculture: Outside and Inside Formal Institutions
abstract: zackheos philippou make case emerging queer art subculture nicosia cyprus tracing way take space discus sexual spatial orientation five artistic curatorial initiative shown nicosia robert mapplethorpes x portfolio aphrodite maroudias despina michaelidous participation urban drag small homeland paola reveniotis correction focusing informal formal venue appropriated nicosia queer art scene argue subculture make strategically variable space gain much desired visibility maintain intimacy within subculture transgress heteronormativitys spatial sexual national boundary
or_abt: Zackheos and Philippou make the case for an emerging queer art subculture in Nicosia, Cyprus, by tracing the ways in which it takes up space. They discuss sexual but also spatial orientation in five artistic and curatorial initiatives shown in Nicosia: Robert Mapplethorpe’s X Portfolio (2009), Re Aphrodite’s At Maroudia’s (2012), Despina Michaelidou’s participation in Urban Drag and Small Homelands (2014) and Paola Revenioti’s Correction (2014 and 2015). Focusing on how informal and formal venues have been appropriated by Nicosia’s queer art scene, they argue that the subculture makes strategically variable use of space to gain much-desired visibility, maintain intimacy within the subculture, and/or transgress heteronormativity’s spatial, sexual, and national boundaries.

title: Comprehensive assessment of Acceptance and Commitment Therapy processes (CompACT): Measure refinement and study of measurement invariance across Portuguese and UK samples
authers: ['Inês A. Trindade', 'Nuno Bravo Ferreira', 'Ana Laura Mendes[...]', 'Nima Golijani-Moghaddam']
abstract: need transnational validation imperative stage development compact self report measure psychological flexibility study aimed translate validate test factor structure portuguese version compact conduct measurement invariance comparing scale performance portuguese uk sample result exploratory factor demonstrated portuguese version compact statistically performed better without item openness experience subscale item portuguese adapted compact presented significant correlation expected direction expected magnitude aaq ii cfq maas caq das partial metric invariance demonstrated portuguese adapted item compact original compact uk sample non correspondence response version may due difference portuguese british culture study contributes adaptation original compact portuguese language refinement instrument item measure psychological flexibility appears adequate portuguese sample lack complete metric invariance compact found across portuguese uk sample highlight importance psychometrically analyzing psychological instrument cultural context distinct targeted measure original validation study
or_abt: The need for a transnational validation is imperative at the stage of development of the CompACT, a self-report measure of psychological flexibility. This study aimed to translate, validate and test the factor structure of the Portuguese version of the CompACT and to conduct a measurement invariance analysis comparing the scale’s performance in Portuguese and UK samples. Results from an Exploratory Factor Analysis demonstrated that the Portuguese version of the CompACT statistically performed better without 5 items from the Openness to Experience subscale. The 18-item Portuguese-adapted CompACT presented significant correlations in the expected directions and with the expected magnitudes with AAQ-II, CFQ-7, MAAS, CAQ-8, and DASS-21. Partial metric invariance was demonstrated between the Portuguese-adapted 18-item CompACT and the original CompACT in a UK sample. The non-correspondence between responses to these versions may be due to differences between the Portuguese and British cultures. This study contributes with the adaptation of the original CompACT to the Portuguese language and with the refinement of this instrument to an 18-item measure of psychological flexibility, that appears to be adequate for use in Portuguese samples. The lack of complete metric invariance of the CompACT found across the Portuguese and UK samples highlights the importance of psychometrically analyzing psychological instruments before use in cultural contexts distinct from the one targeted in the measure’s original validation study.

title: What makes It Difficult to keep an Intimate Relationship: Evidence From Greece and China
abstract: keeping intimate relationship challenging many factor causing strain current employed sample participant china greece intimate relationship classified difficulty keeping intimate relationship factor among common one clinginess long work hour lack personal time space clinginess reported common source relationship strain woman bad sex reported common source relationship strain men fading away enthusiasm bad sex infidelity child reported important older participant lack personal time space character issue reported important younger participant factor structure similar greek chinese cultural context difference addition significant interaction sample sex instance non monogamous factor men gave higher score woman sample difference much pronounced greek sample
or_abt: Keeping an intimate relationship is challenging, and there are many factors causing strain. In the current research, we employed a sample of 1,403 participants from China and Greece who were in an intimate relationship, and we classified 78 difficulties in keeping an intimate relationship in 13 factors. Among the most common ones were clinginess, long work hours, and lack of personal time and space. Clinginess was reported as a more common source of relationship strain by women, while bad sex was reported as a more common source of relationship strain by men. Fading away enthusiasm, bad sex, infidelity and children were reported as more important by older participants, while lack of personal time and space, and character issues were reported as more important by younger participants. The factor structure was similar in the Greek and in the Chinese cultural contexts, but there were also differences. In addition, there were significant interactions between the sample and the sex. For instance, for the non-monogamous factor, men gave higher scores than women in both samples, but the difference was much more pronounced in the Greek sample.

title: Burden of Transport-Related Injuries in the Eastern Mediterranean Region: A Systematic Analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2017
authers: ['GBD EMR Transport Injuries Collaborators', 'Saeid Safiri', 'Mark J M Sullman[...]', 'Mohsen Naghavi']
abstract: background transport related injury ti substantial public health concern region world present study quantified burden ti death eastern mediterranean region emr sex age method ti death estimated age sex country year using cause death ensemble modelling codem dismod mr disability adjusted life year dalys quantify total burden year lost due premature death disability estimated per population estimate reported along corresponding uncertainty interval uis result million ui transport related incident case emr substantial increase million ui age standardized incidence rate emr ui per changed significantly since ui rate differed remarkably country oman ui palestine ui highest lowest age standardized incidence rate per respectively thousand ui transport related fatality emr substantial increase since thousand ui age standardized death rate emr ui per lower found ui somalia ui lebanon ui highest lowest age standardized death rate per respectively age standardised daly rate emr ui per lower read
or_abt:
Background: Transport-related injuries (TIs) are a substantial public health concern for all regions of the world. The present study quantified the burden of TIs and deaths in the Eastern Mediterranean region (EMR) in 2017 by sex and age. Methods: TIs and deaths were estimated by age, sex, country, and year using Cause of Death Ensemble modelling (CODEm) and DisMod-MR 2.1. Disability-adjusted life years (DALYs), which quantify the total burden of years lost due to premature death or disability, were also estimated per 100000 population. All estimates were reported along with their corresponding 95% uncertainty intervals (UIs). Results: In 2017, there were 5.5 million (UI 4.9-6.2) transport-related incident cases in the EMR - a substantial increase from 1990 (2.8 million; UI 2.5-3.1). The age-standardized incidence rate for the EMR in 2017 was 787 (UI 705.5-876.2) per 100000, which has not changed significantly since 1990 (-0.9%; UI -4.7 to 3). These rates differed remarkably between countries, such that Oman (1303.9; UI 1167.3-1441.5) and Palestine (486.5; UI 434.5-545.9) had the highest and lowest age-standardized incidence rates per 100000, respectively. In 2017, there were 185.3 thousand (UI 170.8-200.6) transport-related fatalities in the EMR - a substantial increase since 1990 (140.4 thousand; UI 118.7-156.9). The age-standardized death rate for the EMR in 2017 was 29.5 (UI 27.1-31.9) per 100000, which was 30.5% lower than that found in 1990 (42.5; UI 36.8-47.3). In 2017, Somalia (54; UI 30-77.4) and Lebanon (7.1; UI 4.8-8.6) had the highest and lowest age-standardized death rates per 100,000, respectively. The age-standardised DALY rate for the EMR in 2017 was 1,528.8 (UI 1412.5-1651.3) per 100000, which was 34.4% lower

title: Involuntary singlehood and its causes: The effects of flirting capacity, mating effort, choosiness and capacity to perceive signals of interest
abstract: considerable proportion population involuntarily single want intimate relationship face difficulty current attempted ass possible predictor phenomenon specifically sample greek speaking woman men found participant scored low flirting capacity capacity perceive signal interest mating effort likely involuntarily single intimate relationship experienced longer spell single hood mating effort significant effect voluntary singlehood low scorer likely category high scorer choosiness significant effect voluntary singlehood high scorer likely prefer single low scorer
or_abt: A considerable proportion of the population is involuntarily single; that is, they want to be in an intimate relationship but they face difficulties in doing so. The current paper attempted to assess some possible predictors of this phenomenon. More specifically, in a sample of 1228 Greek-speaking women and men, we found that participants who scored low in flirting capacity, capacity to perceive signals of interest and mating effort, were more likely to be involuntarily single than in an intimate relationship, and experienced longer spells of single-hood. Mating effort had also a significant effect on voluntary singlehood, with low scorers being more likely to be in this category than high scorers. Choosiness had also a significant effect, but only on voluntary singlehood, with high scorers being more likely to prefer to be single than low scorers.

title: Psychometric properties of the Driving Cognitions Questionnaire, Driving Situations Questionnaire, and Driving Behavior Survey
authers: ['Joanne E. Taylor', 'Amanda Stephens', 'Mark J M Sullman']
abstract: driving anxiety common experience significant impact everyday functioning especially avoidance driving travelling car heterogeneity driving anxiety mean treatment often need address multiple area anxiety cognition behaviour psychometric measure important part individualised treatment outcome measurement several measure driving anxiety psychometric property non clinical sample adequately researched present study investigated psychometric property three measure driving anxiety driving cognition questionnaire dcq driving situation questionnaire dsq driving behavior db total participant new zealand electoral roll completed containing three measure driving anxiety measure aberrant driving behaviour driver behaviour questionnaire demographic descriptive variable three driving anxiety scale demonstrated strong concurrent validity dsq strong discriminant validity however discriminant validity finding dcq db mixed needed evidence psychometric property measure driving anxiety maximum benefit designing tailored psychological treatment approach
or_abt: Driving anxiety is a common experience that can have a significant impact on everyday functioning, especially avoidance of driving and travelling in a car. The heterogeneity of driving anxiety means that treatment often needs to address multiple areas of anxiety, cognition, and behaviour, and psychometric measures are an important part of individualised treatment and outcome measurement. There are several measures of driving anxiety, but their psychometric properties in non-clinical samples have not been adequately researched. The present study investigated the psychometric properties of three measures of driving anxiety, the Driving Cognitions Questionnaire (DCQ), Driving Situations Questionnaire (DSQ), and Driving Behavior Survey (DBS). In total, 420 participants from the New Zealand electoral roll completed a survey containing the three measures of driving anxiety, a measure of aberrant driving behaviour (the Driver Behaviour Questionnaire) and demographic and descriptive variables. The three driving anxiety scales demonstrated strong concurrent validity and the DSQ had strong discriminant validity. However, the discriminant validity findings for the DCQ and DBS were mixed. Further research is needed to evidence the psychometric properties of these measures of driving anxiety, so they can be of maximum benefit in designing tailored psychological treatment approaches.

title: Student perceptions of the classroom environment, student characteristics, and motivation for music lessons at secondary school
abstract: suggests often alignment student preference taught music classroom total cypriot secondary school student aged year responded addressing enjoyment music motivation school music lesson perception music classroom environment included questionnaire six subscales involvement affiliation teacher support task orientation order organization rule clarity high rating affiliation teacher support rule clarity suggest overall student perception classroom environment positive uniform varied basis student characteristic girl rated rule clarity higher boy younger student tended rate task orientation order organization rule clarity higher older student higher achieving student tended rate affiliation teacher support higher older boy rated involvement lower younger boy whereas older girl rated involvement higher younger girl inferred boy experienced gradual increase perceived affiliation achievement improved although pattern le consistent girl girl tended report higher motivation school music lesson boy motivation enhanced classroom environment student experienced higher level enjoyment music engagement support teacher finding show music classroom environment characterized student engagement clarity rule good organization clear goal teacher support affiliation classmate
or_abt: The literature suggests that there is often no alignment between student preferences and what and how it is taught in the music classroom. A total of 749 Cypriot secondary school students, aged 12 to 14 years, responded to a survey addressing enjoyment of music, motivation for school music lessons, and perceptions of the music classroom environment. The survey included a questionnaire with six subscales: Involvement, Affiliation, Teacher Support, Task Orientation, Order and Organization, and Rule Clarity. High ratings for Affiliation, Teacher Support, and Rule Clarity suggest that, overall, students’ perceptions of the classroom environment were positive. They were not uniform, but varied on the basis of student characteristics. Girls rated Rule Clarity higher than boys. Younger students tended to rate Task Orientation, Order and Organization, and Rule Clarity higher than older students. Higher-achieving students tended to rate Affiliation and Teacher Support higher. Older boys rated Involvement lower than younger boys, whereas older girls rated Involvement higher than younger girls. It can be inferred that boys experienced a gradual increase in perceived Affiliation as their achievement improved, although the pattern was less consistent for girls. Girls tended to report higher motivation for school music lessons than boys. Motivation was enhanced by classroom environments in which students experienced higher levels of enjoyment of music, engagement, and support from teachers. The findings show that the music classroom environment should be characterized by student engagement, clarity of rules, good organization, clear goals, teacher support, and affiliation between classmates.

title: Development of Social Work Practice and Education in Cyprus
abstract: area work cyprus relatively new researched although historically evidence contributed cypriot society profession work criticised debated public aim explore examine development cypriot work practice education particular attempt present historical evolution work relation socioeconomic cultural political context moreover explores cypriot welfare state main work area work finally critically evaluate current model work education present critical recent development
or_abt: The area of social work in Cyprus is relatively new and under-researched. Although historically there is some evidence of how it has contributed to Cypriot society, the profession of social work has been criticised and debated by the public. The aim of this chapter is to explore and examine the development of Cypriot social work practice and education. In particular, the chapter attempts to present the historical evolution of social work in relation to the socioeconomic, cultural and political context. Moreover, it explores the Cypriot welfare state and the main work areas of social work. Finally, the chapter will critically evaluate the current model of social work education and present a critical analysis of its recent developments.

title: Global, regional and national burden of migraine in 204 countries and territories, 1990-2019
abstract: global burden disease study report burden migraine country territory period systematic point prevalence annual incidence year lived disability yld global age standardised point prevalence annual incidence rate migraine uncertainty interval ui ui per increase ui ui since respectively moreover global age standardised yld rate ui increase ui since global point prevalence migraine higher female increased age age group decreased increased age belgium ui italy ui germany ui highest age standardised point prevalence rate migraine conclusion large intercountry difference burden migraine burden increased significantly across measurement period finding suggest migraine care need included within health system increase population awareness regarding probable risk factor treatment strategy especially among young adult middle aged woman well increase migraine
or_abt: Data from the Global Burden of Disease Study 2019 were used to report the burden of migraine in 204 countries and territories during the period 1990 to 2019, through a systematic analysis of point prevalence, annual incidence, and years lived with disability (YLD). In 2019, the global age-standardised point prevalence and annual incidence rate of migraine were 14,107.3 (95% Uncertainty Interval [UI] 12,270.3-16,239) and 1142.5 (95% UI 995.9-1289.4) per 100,000, an increase of 1.7% (95% UI 0.7%-2.8%) and 2.1% (95% UI 1.1%-2.8%) since 1990, respectively. Moreover, the global age-standardised YLD rate in 2019 was 525.5 (95% UI 78.8-1194), an increase of 1.5% (95% UI -4.4% to 3.3%) since 1990. The global point prevalence of migraine in 2019 was higher in females and increased by age up to the 40 to 44 age group, then decreased with increased age. Belgium (22,400.6 [95% UI: 19,305.2-26,215.8]), Italy (20,337.7 [95% UI: 17,724.7-23,405.8]), and Germany (19,436.4 [95% UI: 16,806.2-22,810.3]) had the 3 highest age-standardised point prevalence rates for migraine in 2019. In conclusion, there were large intercountry differences in the burden of migraine, and this burden increased significantly across the measurement period. These findings suggest that migraine care needs to be included within the health system to increase population awareness regarding the probable risk factors and treatment strategies especially among young adults and middle-aged women, as well as to increase the data on migraines.

title: Reasons of Singles for Being Single: Evidence from Brazil and the UK
authers: ['Menelaos Apostolou', 'Béla Birkás', 'Caio Santos Alves da Silva[...]', 'Yan Wang']
abstract: current aimed examine reason people single intimate relationship across eight different country brazil china czech republic greece hungary india japan uk asked large cross cultural sample single participant n rate different possible reason single reason classified factor including perceived inability find right partner perception good flirting desire focus career significant sex age effect found factor extracted factor classified three separate domain perceived poor capacity attract mate desiring freedom choice currently relationship domain structure relative importance factor domain well sex age effect relatively consistent across country important difference however including differing effect size sex age effect country
or_abt: The current research aimed to examine the reasons people are single, that is, not in an intimate relationship, across eight different countries-Brazil, China, Czech Republic, Greece, Hungary, India, Japan, and the UK. We asked a large cross-cultural sample of single participants (N = 6,822) to rate 92 different possible reasons for being single. These reasons were classified into 12 factors, including one's perceived inability to find the right partner, the perception that one is not good at flirting, and the desire to focus on one's career. Significant sex and age effects were found for most factors. The extracted factors were further classified into three separate domains: Perceived poor capacity to attract mates, desiring the freedom of choice, and currently being in between relationships. The domain structure, the relative importance of each factor and domain, as well as sex and age effects were relatively consistent across countries. There were also important differences however, including the differing effect sizes of sex and age effects between countries.

title: Psychometric Assessment of Adverse Childhood Experiences International Questionnaire (ACE-IQ) with Adults Engaging in Non-Suicidal Self-Injury
abstract: background current study aimed investigate psychometric property adverse childhood experience international questionnaire ace iq individual engaging non suicidal self injury numerous study supported association adverse childhood experience non suicidal self injury however majority measure limited basic form abuse neglect indicating need inclusive measure ace iq psychometric property measure though briefly investigated population suggesting thorough examination might beneficial method hundred eighty four adult participant female mean age sd recruited online via specific self harm group medium platform participant asked complete online consisting three self report measure regarding early childhood experience engagement non suicidal self injury result finding study supported ace iq reliability cronbachs alpha convergent validity r p ctq sf predictive validity r² p shi total score discriminant validity f value p exploration factor structure demonstrated factor solution physical abuse sexual abuse emotional abuse exposure violence family environment conclusion concluded ace iq reliable valid measure clinical purpose individual engaging non suicidal self injury although needed factor structure clinical implication discussed
or_abt: Background: The current study aimed to investigate the psychometric properties of the Adverse Childhood Experiences – International Questionnaire (ACE-IQ) with individuals engaging in non-suicidal self-injury. Numerous studies have supported the association of adverse childhood experiences with non-suicidal self-injury. However, the majority of the measures used were limited to basic forms of abuse and neglect, indicating a need for the use of a more inclusive measure, such as the ACE-IQ. The psychometric properties of the measure though have only been briefly investigated with other populations, suggesting that a more thorough examination might be beneficial before its use. Method: Two hundred eighty-four adult participants (77.5% females) with a mean age of 23.4 (SD=5.7) were recruited online via specific self-harm groups on social media platforms. Participants were asked to complete an online survey consisting of three self-report measures regarding early childhood experiences and engagement in non-suicidal self-injury. Results: The findings of this study supported ACE-IQ’s reliability (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.854), convergent validity (r= 0.85, p<0.001 with the CTQ-SF), predictive validity (R² = 0.12, p=0.001 of the SHI total score) and discriminant validity (F-value = 13.90, p<0.001). An exploration of the factor structure demonstrated a 5-factor solution (physical abuse, sexual abuse, emotional abuse, exposure to violence, family environment). Conclusions: It was concluded that ACE-IQ is a reliable and valid measure to be used for research or clinical purposes with individuals engaging in non-suicidal self-injury, although further research is needed on its factor structure. Research and clinical implications are discussed.

title: Prevalence, deaths and disability-adjusted-life-years (DALYs) due to asthma and its attributable risk factors in 204 countries and territories, 1990-2019
authers: ['Saeid Safiri', 'Kristin V Carson-Chahhoud', 'Nahid Karamzad[...]', 'Jay S. Kaufman']
abstract: background understanding global trend point prevalence death disability adjusted life year dalys asthma facilitate evidence based decision making question global regional national burden asthma country territory age sex socio demographic index sdi study design method publicly available global burden disease study period estimate presented count age standardised rate per along associated uncertainty interval uis result global age standardised point prevalence death rate asthma per represent decrease since respectively moreover global age standardised daly rate global point prevalence asthma highest age group usa highest age standardised point prevalence rate asthma generally burden asthma decreased increasing socio demographic index sdi globally high body mass index smoking occupational asthmagens contributed asthma dalys interpretation asthma remains important public health issue particularly region low socio economic development future needed thoroughly examine association asthma risk factor factor impeding optimal self management needed understand better implement intervention reduced burden asthma
or_abt: Background Understanding global trends in the point prevalence, deaths and disability adjusted life years (DALYs) for asthma will facilitate evidence-based decision making. Research Question What is the global, regional and national burden of asthma in 204 countries and territories between 1990 and 2019, by age, sex and socio-demographic index (SDI)? Study Design and Methods Publicly available data from the Global Burden of Disease study were used over the period 1990 to 2019. All estimates were presented as counts and age-standardised rates per 100,000, along with their associated uncertainty intervals (UIs). Results In 2019, the global age-standardised point prevalence and death rates for asthma were 3415.5 and 5.8 per 100,000, which represent a 24% and 51.3% decrease since 1990, respectively. Moreover, in 2019 the global age-standardised DALY rate was 273.6 and the global point prevalence of asthma was highest in the 5-9 age group. Also in 2019, the USA (10399.3) had the highest age-standardised point prevalence rate of asthma. Generally, the burden of asthma decreased with increasing socio-demographic index (SDI). Globally, high body mass index (16.9%), smoking (9.9%) and occupational asthmagens (8.8%) contributed to the 2019 asthma DALYs. Interpretation Asthma remains an important public health issue, particularly in regions with low socio-economic development. Future research is needed to thoroughly examine the associations asthma has with its risk factors and the factors impeding optimal self-management. Further research is also needed to understand and better implement the interventions that have reduced the burden of asthma.

title: Parental Influence and Sexual Selection
abstract: address genetic relatedness parent child result party converging well diverging interest domain mating interest along factor trade offs inherent mating give rise opportunity cost free mate choice parent much lose allow child exercise choice freely opportunity cost provides strong incentive parent influence child mate choice preindustrial society parent manage exercise direct control predominantly manifested institution arranged marriage postindustrial society parent exercise influence indirectly manipulation ultimately parental influence mating give rise sexual selection force namely parental choice may unique human specie
or_abt: This chapter addresses how the genetic relatedness between parents and their children results in the two parties having converging as well as diverging interests. In the domain of mating, these interests, along with other factors such as the trade-offs inherent in mating, give rise to an opportunity cost of free mate choice: Parents have much to lose if they allow their children to exercise choice freely. This opportunity cost provides a strong incentive to parents to influence their children's mate choices. In preindustrial societies, parents manage to exercise direct control, which is predominantly manifested in the institution of arranged marriage. In postindustrial societies, parents exercise influence indirectly through manipulation. Ultimately, parental influence over mating gives rise to a sexual selection force, namely parental choice, which may be unique to the human species.

title: Parent-offspring conflict
abstract: relationship parent child dictated genetic interest however completely overlapping particular child share allele parent mean genetic interest partially converge partially diverge present discus divergence interest related implication field evolutionary psychology parent offspring conflict mating manifested allocation parental investment child want fair share parental resource mating another domain parent offspring conflict mating manifested individual child consider optimal mate considered optimal law parent conflict interest result parental attempt control childrens mate choice childrens attempt escape control parental control mating successful affect course sexual selection thus evolutionary trajectory adaptation related mating
or_abt: The relationships of parents and children are dictated by their genetic interests, which are not however completely overlapping. In particular, children share 50% of their alleles with their parents, which means that their genetic interests partially converge and partially diverge. The present chapter discusses divergence of interests and the related research and implications for the field of evolutionary psychology. Parent-offspring conflict over mating is manifested in the allocation of parental investment, where children want more than their fair share of parental resources. Mating is another domain where parent-offspring conflict over mating is manifested. The individuals who children consider optimal as mates are not considered optimal as in-laws by their parents. This conflict of interests results in parental attempts to control children’s mate choices, and children’s attempts to escape from this control. Parental control over mating, when successful, can affect the course of sexual selection and thus, the evolutionary trajectory of adaptations related to mating.

title: The Lesbian Space of Contemporary Greek-Cypriot Art
abstract: trace way greek cypriot self confessed lesbian artist charitini kyriakou take space visual work examines sexual spatial orientation kyriakous artistic curatorial practice focusing four solo exhibition last decade month stay μήνες μείνε personal person προσωπικά μου πρόσωπα room δωμάτια desire erebus του πόθου το ερεβώδες shown lesbian space kyriakou agrees lesbian assembling practice highlight everyday site creativity delight protection privilege inner world assumes lesbian habitus deportment disposition attire well transgresses heteronormativitys spatial sexual national boundary
or_abt: This paper traces the ways Greek-Cypriot self-confessed lesbian artist Charitini Kyriakou takes up space in her visual work. It examines the sexual and spatial orientation in Kyriakou’s artistic and curatorial practices by focusing on four of her solo exhibitions from the last decade: ‘Months Stay’ («Μήνες Μείνε») (2010), ‘My Personal Persons’ («Προσωπικά μου Πρόσωπα») (2011), ‘Rooms’ («Δωμάτια») (2016) and ‘Desire’s Erebus’ («Του Πόθου το Ερεβώδες») (2018). As will be shown, the lesbian space of Kyriakou agrees with lesbian assembling practices, highlights the everyday as a site of creativity, delight, and protection, privileges the inner world, assumes a lesbian habitus through deportment, disposition, and attire, as well as transgresses heteronormativity’s spatial, sexual, and national boundaries.

title: Global, regional, and national burden of Guillain-Barré syndrome and its underlying causes from 1990 to 2019
abstract: background present first detailed prevalence disability burden guillainbarré syndrome gb cause age sex socio demographic index sdi country territory method global burden disease study gbd gbd modelled prevalence gb using hospital claim year lived disability ylds estimated product gb prevalence disability weight reported proportion age standardised prevalence rate due six underlying cause gb result uncertainty interval ui total case gb worldwide resulted ui ylds globally ui increase age standardised prevalence gb per population high income asia pacific ui east asia ui highest lowest age standardised prevalence rate per respectively nationally japan ui china ui highest lowest age standardised prevalence rate per age standardised burden gb increased increasing age higher male age group furthermore age standardised prevalence gb per positive association level development measured sdi although association strong upper respiratory infection unknown cause accounted highest proportion underlying cause conclusion globally prevalence gb continues increas read
or_abt:
Background This article presents the first detailed analysis of the prevalence and disability burden of Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS) from 1990 to 2019 by cause, age, sex, and Socio-demographic Index (SDI) in 204 countries and territories. Methods Data from the Global Burden of Diseases Study (GBD) 2019 were used. GBD 2019 modelled the prevalence of GBS using hospital and claims data. Years lived with disability (YLDs) were estimated as the product of the GBS prevalence and the disability weight. This article also reported proportions in the age-standardised prevalence rate that were due to six underlying causes of GBS. Results In 2019, there were 150,095 [95% uncertainty intervals (UI) 119,924 to 188,309] total cases of GBS worldwide, which resulted in 44,407 (95% UI 28,016 to 64,777) YLDs. Globally, there was a 6.4% (95% UI 3.6 to 9.5) increase in the age-standardised prevalence of GBS per 100,000 population between 1990 and 2019. High-income Asia Pacific [1.9 (95% UI: 1.5 to 2.4)] and East Asia [0.8 (95% UI: 0.6 to 1.0)] had the highest and lowest age-standardised prevalence rates (per 100,000), respectively, in 2019. Nationally, Japan [6.4 (95% UI: 5.3 to 7.7)] and China [0.8 (95% UI: 0.6 to 1.0)] had the highest and lowest age-standardised prevalence rates (per 100,000). The age-standardised burden of GBS increased with increasing age and was higher in males in all age groups. Furthermore, the age-standardised prevalence of GBS (per 100,000) had a positive association with the level of development, as measured by SDI, although this association was not strong. Upper respiratory infections and unknown causes accounted for the highest proportions of underlying causes. Conclusions Globally, the prevalence of GBS continues to increas

title: Partner's traits which motivate people to stay in an intimate relationship: An explorative analysis
abstract: intimate relationship vary long last current study attempted identify partner trait associated longer relationship length better perceived relationship prospect particular study employed open ended questionnaire depth interview sample greek speaking participant identified partner trait motivate people continue intimate relationship using quantitative method sample greek speaking participant study classified trait broader factor faithful trustworthy well friend family factor associated year relationship furthermore faithful trustworthy give sexual satisfaction committed fun factor positive effect perceived prospect current relationship mediated relationship satisfaction addition well friend family direct positive effect relationship prospect
or_abt: Intimate relationships vary in how long they last, and the current study attempted to identify partners' traits which are associated with longer relationship length and better perceived relationship prospects. In particular, Study 1 employed open-ended questionnaires and in-depth interviews in a sample of 207 Greek-speaking participants , and identified 75 partner traits which motivate people to continue an intimate relationship. Using quantitative research methods in a sample of 1189 Greek-speaking participants, Study 2 classified these traits in 11 broader factors. The "Faithful and trustworthy" and the "Does well with my friends and family" factors, were associated with more years in a relationship. Furthermore, the "Faithful and trustworthy," the "Gives me sexual satisfaction," the "Committed to me" and the "Fun to be with" factors, had a positive effect on the perceived prospects of the current relationship, which was mediated by relationship satisfaction. In addition, the "Does well with my friends and family," had a direct positive effect on relationship prospects.

title: The Tabriz Older People Survey (TOPS-2019): A community-based cross-sectional study
authers: ['Mostafa Araj-Khodaei', 'Sarvin Sanaie', 'Seyed Aria Nejadghaderi[...]', 'Akbar Azizi Zeinalhajlou']
abstract: background population aging consequence area substantial global concern growth number older people important factor increasing burden non communicable disease ncds society tabriz older people top aimed understand socio demographic health related behavior health profile older adult method cross sectional study conducted representative sample community dwelling older adult tabriz populated city northwest iran sampling method probability proportionate size pps collection conducted household participant summer winter trained interviewer administered questionnaire measured socio demographic anthropometrics support sleep quality mental health past medical history dietary habit traditional medicine physical activity health related behavior result sample consisted fameless young older people year old almost half sample completely illiterate daily walking sample woman reporting sedentary lifestyle male participant current smoker higher male v people lived alone woman term sleep quality anxiety depression cognitive status daily functioning support men significantly better woman hypertension stroke least common underlying disease v conclusion finding suggest older woman signifi read
or_abt:
Background: Population aging and its consequences area substantial global concern. The growth in the numbers of older people is one of the most important factors increasing the burden of non-communicable diseases (NCDs) on society. The Tabriz Older People Survey (TOPS) aimed to understand the socio-demographics, health-related behaviors, and health profile of older adults. Methods: This cross-sectional study was conducted on a representative sample of 1362 community dwelling older adults in Tabriz, the most populated city in the northwest of Iran. The sampling method was probability proportionate to size (PPS). Data collection was conducted in the households of the participants from summer 2019 to winter 2020. Trained interviewers administered the questionnaire, which measured socio-demographics, anthropometrics, social support, sleep quality, mental health, past medical history, dietary habits, traditional medicine, physical activity, and other health-related behaviors. Results: The sample of 1362 consisted of 56.4% fameless and 54.4% were young older people (60-69 years old). Almost half of the sample were completely illiterate. There was no daily walking in 13.3% of the sample, with women reporting a more sedentary lifestyle than males. Out of the 1362 participants, 135 (9.9%) were current smokers, which was higher in males (20.9% vs. 1.5%) and more than 88% of people who lived alone were women. In terms of sleep quality, anxiety, depression, cognitive status, daily functioning, and social support, men were significantly better than women. Hypertension and stroke were the most and least common underlying diseases (81.0% vs. 6.2%). Conclusions: The findings suggest that older women are signifi

title: An evidence-based analysis of the psychosocial adaptability of conflict-exposed adolescents and the role of the education system as a protective environment
abstract: ongoing armed conflict eastern ukraine fifth year remains omnipresent daily life young people across country including far reaching socio economic consequence living near contact line continued exposure shelling military operation study based collected among adolescent aged randomly selected school government controlled area donetsk luhansk oblasts provides ecological evidence driven approach exploring firstly conflict exposure adversity impact key development outcome secondly life skill school connectedness family connectedness provide protective buffer specifically study found conflict exposure associated broad range internalizing externalizing mental health problem whereas exposure micro systemic violence e g family abuse school victimization additionally associated school drop tendency reduced readiness civic participation source resilience study found collaborative skill executive skill combination parent support teacher support contribute resilience adolescent exposed violence microsystem contrast adolescent resilient face conflict exposure likely characterized supportive relationship peer emotional connection school inter dependent value collaborative problem solving skill tolerance diversity study go explore greater detail specific role played education system measured concept school connecte read
or_abt:
The ongoing armed conflict in eastern Ukraine, now in its fifth year, remains omnipresent in the daily lives of young people across the country including through its far-reaching socio-economic consequences and, for those living near the contact line, continued exposure to shelling and military operations. This study, based on analysis of data collected among 3,331 adolescents aged 13-17 from 48 randomly selected schools in government-controlled areas of Donetsk and Luhansk oblasts, provides an ecological and evidence-driven approach to exploring, firstly, how conflict exposure and other adversities impact on key development outcomes, and secondly, how life skills, school connectedness and family connectedness can provide protective buffers. Specifically, the study found that conflict exposure is associated with a broad range of internalizing and externalizing mental health problems; whereas exposure to micro-systemic violence (e.g. family abuse, school victimization) is additionally associated with school drop-out tendency and reduced readiness for civic participation. As for sources of resilience, the study found that collaborative skills and executive skills, in combination with parent support and teacher support, contribute most to resilience in adolescents exposed to violence in their microsystem. In contrast, adolescents that are resilient in the face of conflict exposure are more likely to be characterized by supportive relationships with peers, emotional connection to the school, inter-dependent values, collaborative problem-solving skills and tolerance of diversity. The study then goes on to explore in greater detail the specific role that can be played by the education system, measured through the concept of school connecte

title: Informalisation and Flexibilisation at Work: The Migrant Woman Precariat Speaks
abstract: biographical interview migrant woman across eu country illustrate cope employment integration irregular immigration micro individual level proposes rethinking integration related policy locating problem area mechanism intervention regulation informal labour market severely curtailed neoliberal reform since therefore immigration labour policy generating reproducing vulnerable irregular occupying marginal labour market position migrant woman represent core global precariat public debate irregular work migrant particularly migrant woman generally misrepresent reality narrated migrant worker author argue emancipation narrative reform proposal ought take account coping practice migrant woman towards restrictive immigration labour market policy
or_abt: The biographical interviews with migrant women across 11 EU countries illustrate how they cope with employment, integration and irregular immigration at the micro- and individual level. This chapter proposes a rethinking of the integration-related policies by locating the problem areas. Mechanisms for intervention and regulation of the informal labour markets have been severely curtailed by the neoliberal reforms since the 1980s. Therefore, immigration and labour policies are generating and reproducing vulnerable irregulars occupying marginal labour market positions; migrant women represent the core of the global precariat. Also, public debates on irregular work by migrants and particularly migrant women generally misrepresent the social realities as narrated by migrant workers themselves. The authors argue that any emancipation narrative or any reform proposal ought to take into account the coping practices of migrant women towards restrictive immigration and labour market policies

title: Perceptions of the appropriate response to norm violation in 57 societies
authers: ['Kimmo Ericsson', 'Pontus Strimling', 'Michele Gelfand[...]', 'Paul A M Van Lange']
abstract: norm enforcement may important resolving conflict promoting cooperation however little known preferred response norm violation vary across culture across domain preregistered study country using convenience sample student non student measured perception appropriateness various response violation cooperative norm atypical behavior finding highlight cultural universal cultural variation find universal negative relation appropriateness rating norm violation appropriateness rating response form confrontation ostracism gossip moreover find country variation appropriateness sanction consistent across different norm violation across different sanction specifically country physical confrontation ostracism rated le appropriate gossip rated appropriate
or_abt: Norm enforcement may be important for resolving conflicts and promoting cooperation. However, little is known about how preferred responses to norm violations vary across cultures and across domains. In a preregistered study of 57 countries (using convenience samples of 22,863 students and non-students), we measured perceptions of the appropriateness of various responses to a violation of a cooperative norm and to atypical social behaviors. Our findings highlight both cultural universals and cultural variation. We find a universal negative relation between appropriateness ratings of norm violations and appropriateness ratings of responses in the form of confrontation, social ostracism and gossip. Moreover, we find the country variation in the appropriateness of sanctions to be consistent across different norm violations but not across different sanctions. Specifically, in those countries where use of physical confrontation and social ostracism is rated as less appropriate, gossip is rated as more appropriate.

title: The Palgrave Handbook of Family Sociology in Europe
abstract: handbook provides excellent blend reassessment reflection know know family intimate life europe critical overview new insight offered across carefully chosen range starting point lynn jamieson professor sociology university edinburgh uk series editor palgrave macmillan study family intimate life handbook excellent compendium recent scholarship sociology family european scholar valuable resource american scholar wish keep best europe andrew cherlin professor sociology public policy john hopkins university usa handbook provides meaningful overview topical theme within family sociology academic field well empirical reality various societal context across europe sixty prominent european scholar original text present field main theoretical methodological approach addition issue family relationship parental arrangement parenting practice child well family policy welfare state regime family life migration family trajectory presenting cutting edge finding theoretical interpretation solution methodological challenge timely tool researcher teacher student family practitioner wish familiarise state family sociology europe
or_abt: ‘The handbook provides an excellent blend of reassessment and reflection on what we know and how we know about families and intimate lives in Europe. Critical overviews and new insights are offered across a carefully chosen range of starting points.’ —Lynn Jamieson, Professor of Sociology, University of Edinburgh, UK, and series editor for Palgrave Macmillan Studies in Family and Intimate Life ‘This handbook is an excellent compendium of recent scholarship on the sociology of the family by European scholars. It will be a valuable resource for American scholars who wish to keep up with the best research in Europe.’ —Andrew Cherlin, Professor of Sociology and Public Policy, Johns Hopkins University, USA This handbook provides a meaningful overview of topical themes within family sociology as an academic field as well as empirical realities in various societal contexts across Europe. More than sixty prominent European scholars’ original texts present the field’s main theoretical and methodological approaches in addition to issues such as families as relationships, parental arrangements, parenting practices and child well-being, family policies in welfare state regimes, family lives in migration, and family trajectories. Presenting cutting-edge research on findings, theoretical interpretations, and solutions to methodological challenges, it is a timely tool for researchers, teachers, students, and family practitioners who wish to familiarise themselves with the state of family sociology in Europe.

title: Assessing inequalities in geographical access to emergency medical services in metropolitan Lisbon: a cross-sectional and ecological study
abstract: objective study suggested material deprivation strongly associated negative health outcome lower usage various level healthcare aim analyse geographical access emergency medical service em hospital emergency unit em relation deprivation lisbon metropolitan area lma portugal design study estimate road network based access time centroid statistical section census block group equivalent location em hospital emergency service statistical section linked material deprivation index mdi non parametric variance anova undertaken compare mdi linked statistical section term access emergency care geographical access conducted primary outcome measure road network based access time minute em statistical section emergency unit hospital result overall lma population located le min drive em without transport em transport travel time em transport hospital potentially le min population however resident living beyond min threshold total time emergency call hospital arrival area high mdi high mdi medium mdi low mdi low mdi kruskal wallis anova confirms discrepancy access time better poorer area conclusion poorer area experience worse geographical access em hospital emergency unit needed explore quality service outco read
or_abt:
Objectives Studies have suggested that material deprivation is strongly associated with negative health outcomes, and lower usage of various levels of healthcare. We aim to analyse geographical access to emergency medical services (EMSs) and hospital emergency units by EMS in relation to deprivation in the Lisbon Metropolitan Area (LMA), Portugal. Design This study estimates road network-based access times from the centroids of statistical sections (census block groups equivalent) to locations of EMS and hospital emergency services. Each statistical section has been linked to a Material Deprivation Index (MDI). A non-parametric analysis of variance (ANOVA) was undertaken to compare MDI-linked statistical sections in terms of access to emergency care. Geographical access analysis was conducted for 2018. Primary outcome measure Road network-based access time (in minutes) for EMSs to statistical sections and then on to emergency units in hospitals. Results Overall, 82.4% of the LMA population is located less than a 10 min drive from an EMS without transport, and 99.1% from an EMS with transport. Travel time from EMS with transport to hospital is potentially less than 20 min for 95.2% of the population. However, 63.1% of residents living beyond a 30 min threshold (total time from emergency call to hospital arrival) are in areas with very high MDI (18.8% in high MDI, 13.3% in medium MDI, 4.7% in low MDI, 0% in very low MDI). Kruskal-Wallis ANOVA confirms discrepancies in access times between better-off and poorer areas. Conclusion Poorer areas experience worse geographical access to EMS and hospital emergency units. More research is needed to explore the quality of services and their outco

title: How Can Polycentricity of Territorial Development Improve Functional Integration? NATIONS UNIES - ОБЪЕДИНЕННЫЕ НАЦИИ - UNITED NATIONS
abstract: explores concept polycentricity expected contribution balanced territorial development inclusion different spatial scale focus influence city facilitating competitiveness innovation growth harnessing synergy polycentric network cooperation coordination complementarity discus governance partnership best assist implementation polycentric development
or_abt: This paper explores the concept of polycentricity and its expected contribution to more balanced territorial development and social inclusion at different spatial scales. The paper focuses on the influence of cities in facilitating competitiveness, innovation and growth by harnessing the synergy of polycentric networks of cooperation, coordination and complementarity. It discusses governance and partnerships and how they can best assist the implementation of polycentric development.

title: Payments for Ecosystem Services and Rural Transition to Sustainability. A critical assessment.
abstract: ecosystem service e commonly understood benefit humankind obtains nature order satisfy need time fulfil specie requirement costanza et al mea designed aim capture value nature represent society concept e gradually introduced realm market gómez baggethun et al nowadays argued payment ecosystem service pe help reverse degradation ecosystem service biodiversity even help restore latter furthermore said reduce poverty create novel urbanrural compact since transfer fund consumer e provider responsible provision kosoy corbera p heavy critique arisen utilitarian approach nature especially mainstreaming economic approach nature cf gómez baggethun et al mccaubley corbera et al however still seen dominant mechanism attain sustainability author even proposing significantly altered reframed pe could help trigger transition sustainability muniz cruz realm positioned double aim inquiring pe mechanism function order find main limitation constraint approach value ecosystem undertaking look hypothetical case rural unsustainable community southern europe ask premise pe mechanism could help community transition real sustainability state framed transition read
or_abt:
Ecosystem services (ES) are commonly understood as the benefits humankind obtains from nature in order to satisfy their needs and that, at the same time, fulfil other species requirements (Costanza et al., 1997; MEA, 2005). Designed with the aim to capture the value that nature should represent for society, the concept of ES has been gradually introduced into the realm of the market (Gómez-Baggethun et al., 2010). Nowadays, it is argued that Payments for Ecosystem Services (PES) help to reverse the degradation of ecosystems, its services and biodiversity and even help to restore the latter. Furthermore, it is said to reduce poverty and create a novel “urban–rural compact” since it transfers funds from consumers of ES to the providers responsible for their provisions (Kosoy & Corbera, 2010, p. 1228). Heavy critiques have arisen of the utilitarian approach to nature, especially the mainstreaming of the economic approach to nature (cf. Gómez-Baggethun et al., 2010; McCaubley, 2006; Corbera et al., 2007). However, they are still seen as the dominant mechanism to attain sustainability. Some authors are even proposing that, if significantly altered and reframed, PES could help to trigger a transition to sustainability (Muniz & Cruz, 2015). It is in this realm that our paper has to be positioned. It has the double aim of 1) inquiring into how the PES mechanism functions, in order to 2) find out which are the main limitations and constraints of this approach to value ecosystems. For this undertaking we look at the hypothetical case of a rural unsustainable community in Southern Europe and ask ourselves under which premises the PES mechanism could help the community to transition to a real sustainability state, framed by the transition literature.
