title: Fairy tales, copyright, and the public domain
abstract: ailing han christian andersen traveled switzerland sought treatment spa glion high lake geneva drinking daily dos whey cure brought affluent people europe swiss resort whey nothing surprising considering year later died cancer likelihood already suffering family hamburg stayed room directly mr mai wife young daughter andersen kept company among guest spa thursday may record diary weather doesnt look promising today either slept many interruption slept nonetheless ringworm itch constantly many small liver spot leg mean letter mr melchior simon henriques visit mr mai maintained story old man taken grimm told danish folktale grimm never composed fairy tale collector good mood old man always right appeared second series andersen new fairy tale story time andersen easily scandinavia famous author internationally acclaimed fairy tale already translated many time number language introductory remark complete collection tale published year mr mais read
or_abt:
In 1873, an ailing Hans Christian Andersen traveled to Switzerland, where he sought treatment at a spa in Glion, high above Lake Geneva, drinking daily doses of whey - a cure that brought affluent people from all over Europe to Swiss resorts. The whey did nothing for him. Not surprising considering that two years later he died of a cancer from which he was in all likelihood already suffering. A family from Hamburg stayed in the room directly above him, a Mr. Mai, his wife, and their young daughter. Andersen kept company with them, among other guests in the spa, and on Thursday, May 29, he records in his diary: The weather doesn’t look promising today either. I slept with many interruptions, but slept nonetheless. My ringworm itches constantly and I have many small liver spots on my legs, what does that mean? A letter from Mrs. Melchior and from Simon Henriques. A visit from Mr. Mai, who maintained that the story about "What the Old Man Does" was taken from Grimm. I told him it was a Danish folktale and that Grimm had never composed a fairy tale, he was only a collector… I am not in a good mood. "What the Old Man Does Is Always Right" appeared in 1861 in the second series of Andersen’s New Fairy Tales and Stories. By this time, Andersen was easily Scandinavia’s most famous author, internationally acclaimed for his fairy tales that had already been translated many times into a number of languages. In introductory remarks to a complete collection of his tales published in 1874, a year after Mr. Mai’s
… Read more

title: Genome-wide association study identifies sequence variants on 6q21 associated with age at menarche
abstract: earlier menarche correlate shorter adult height higher childhood body fat conducted genome wide association study age menarche aam icelandic woman combined replication set iceland denmark netherlands n yielded significant association r q near lin b gene aam effect month later per allele p second snp within linkage disequilibrium ld block r split r haplotype different effect month month per allele variant associated greater adult height association adult height account association aam vice versa variant previously associated height associate significantly aam given link body fat aam assessed variant recently associated higher body mass index bmi associated earlier aam
or_abt: Earlier menarche correlates with shorter adult height and higher childhood body fat. We conducted a genome-wide association study of age at menarche (AAM) on 15,297 Icelandic women. Combined analysis with replication sets from Iceland, Denmark and the Netherlands (N = 10,040) yielded a significant association between rs314280[T] on 6q21, near the LIN28B gene, and AAM (effect = 1.2 months later per allele; P = 1.8 × 10(-14)). A second SNP within the same linkage disequilibrium (LD) block, rs314277, splits rs314280[T] into two haplotypes with different effects (0.9 months and 1.9 months per allele). These variants have been associated with greater adult height. The association with adult height did not account for the association with AAM or vice versa. Other variants, previously associated with height, did not associate significantly with AAM. Given the link between body fat and AAM, we also assessed 11 variants recently associated with higher body mass index (BMI) and 5 of those associated with earlier AAM.

title: Mobilizing the Arctic Polar Bears and Puffins in Transnational Interplay
abstract: investigates role symbolic meaning puffin polar bear within trans cultural context narrative material culture iceland past present investigates animal travel beyond edge habitat midst urban landscape diverse form representation
or_abt: This chapter investigates the roles and symbolic meanings of puffins and polar bears within the trans-cultural context of narrative and material culture in Iceland's past and present. It investigates how these animals travel beyond the edges of their habitat and into the midst of urban landscapes in diverse forms and representations.

title: Common variants on 9q22.33 and 14q13.3 predispose to thyroid cancer in European populations
abstract: order search sequence variant conferring risk thyroid cancer conducted genome wide association study icelandic case control respectively followed replication study individual european descent show common variant located q q associated disease overall strongest association signal observed r q p x r q p x gene nearest q locus foxe ttf nkx ttf among gene located q locus variant contribute increased risk papillary follicular thyroid cancer approximately individual homozygous variant estimated risk thyroid cancer fold greater noncarriers study large sample set general population risk allele associated low concentration thyroid stimulating hormone tsh q allele associated low concentration thyroxin high concentration triiodothyronine
or_abt: In order to search for sequence variants conferring risk of thyroid cancer we conducted a genome-wide association study in 192 and 37,196 Icelandic cases and controls, respectively, followed by a replication study in individuals of European descent. Here we show that two common variants, located on 9q22.33 and 14q13.3, are associated with the disease. Overall, the strongest association signals were observed for rs965513 on 9q22.33 (OR = 1.75; P = 1.7 x 10(-27)) and rs944289 on 14q13.3 (OR = 1.37; P = 2.0 x 10(-9)). The gene nearest to the 9q22.33 locus is FOXE1 (TTF2) and NKX2-1 (TTF1) is among the genes located at the 14q13.3 locus. Both variants contribute to an increased risk of both papillary and follicular thyroid cancer. Approximately 3.7% of individuals are homozygous for both variants, and their estimated risk of thyroid cancer is 5.7-fold greater than that of noncarriers. In a study on a large sample set from the general population, both risk alleles are associated with low concentrations of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), and the 9q22.33 allele is associated with low concentration of thyroxin (T(4)) and high concentration of triiodothyronine (T(3)).
